Mohan151 Essays – S.C. GuptaIAS Mains GS Ethics – ArihantLexicon for Ethics, Integrity and AptitudeChallenges to Internal Security of IndiaAnd more… How to prepare for the UPSC CSE Exam Here are some tips to crack the UPSC Civil Services Exam and become an IAS, IPS or IFS officer. Watch your Routine One of the biggest roadblocks for the CSE is the time management. The exam is conducted over three stages – the Preliminary, Main and the Interview. Each has a pretty large syllabus and the exam extends over a year. Most aspirants are full-time students or office-goers who have to schedule their preparation within the time they can manage outside of their regular routine. Being serious about the exam requires a steady focus, and thus a separate time-table to ensure a consistent approach towards assimilating the vast amount of information for the exam. This time management is only possible if the candidates are able to set up a schedule and fix deadlines for when they intend to cover the various portions of the syllabus. For instance, studying and making notes for at least a few hours every day for 10 days to cover the basic concepts of Geography. The process and the individual timelines may vary but working out the strategy for time management is essential to everyone. Last minute cramming has hardly, or rather rarely, worked for most CSE candidates. It is also important to realize that a lot of the time to study will actually involve revisiting concepts you have already studied. So, set aside time for regular revisions and workout your brain regularly. Understand the Exam Pattern The UPSC website clearly states the intention of their test. It is to find individuals who need not have a specialized in-depth understanding of the topics but rather a comprehensive awareness of the history, culture, geography, and other functional aspects of India and a bit of the world. Questions may get specialized in the Optional Subject papers, but only as much as somewhat more than an undergraduate level, ie at an Honor’s level. In the case of Engineering, Medicine, and Law, an undergraduate understanding is sufficient. Familiarize yourself with the extent of the syllabus, so you can start structuring your study plan accordingly. The syllabus, for each section, is detailed on the upsc website. Plan a Structured Study The volume of information, towards an exhaustive preparation, may seem intimidating. Therefore, it is easier to structure the study plan concentrating on building on the basic concepts, usually from the recommended NCERT books. It is a good idea to find multiple source materials, while not overwhelming your schedule with too many books. Candidates often even refer to online material for information. The secret, as many veterans have mentioned before, is to comfortably understand the basic concepts without taking the aid of rote learning schemes. ‘Coz memorizing may land you in trouble by virtue of the vastness of the syllabus. Practice Testing It is essential to keep up a regular habit of writing, reading, analysing, and examining, a content. Many successful candidates have stressed on the importance of having regular discussions and debates with their friends and colleagues, on topics associated with the syllabus and current affairs. It provides an excellent practice for logically presenting your views while also helping you to understand the depth of your insights. There are many free mock tests available online to examine your preparation in a timed fashion. These can help in getting all your gears in action as required on the day of the exam. Although the exam coordinators are known to almost never repeat questions from previous years, the previous question papers do provide a glimpse of the type of questions preferred by them. You can judge the difficulty level, relevance to the prescribed syllabus, depth of required understanding, analytical and logical complexity, and scoring, by revising your performance on questions that have been asked before. Revision is a Priority The length and breadth of the CSE exam requires regular revisits to the study material. Your preparation schedule should cover the time needed to revise the read topics multiple times. It is often useful to highlight important passages, or make notes, for a quick look close to the exam date. Make sure you have such a provision for the sake of efficiency. Updated Current Affairs A lot of questions are associated with the candidate’s general awareness of topical affairs in the world, with emphasis on the happenings in India. Get in the habit of reading a multitude of daily newspapers to stay abreast of current topics. Various sources recommend The Hindu, Economist, The Indian Express, All India Radio News, Parliamentary discussions, regional language newspapers, and magazines like Yojana, India and Manorama Year Books. Stay Healthy and Engaged Finally, set aside time to look up from your books and interact with other people. The CSE exams are taxing on not just the candidate but also the people around them. It is important to not ignore your communication skills and your general emotional well-being. Eat and sleep well, engage yourself in other activities, and don’t let the weight of the exam stress you out. The UPSC CSE exam is designed so that a candidate’s efforts, dedication, strategizing, planning, logic, analytical powers, and overall quick thinking, are rewarded. In that sense, every candidate’s life experiences also play a role in their preparation. How else would you explain a syllabus that essentially tests the ability to absorb the political, cultural, historical, and geographical, environment that one lives in? The actual CSE preparation then simply boils down to polishing on the knowledge that you would have anyway imbibed as a student and a citizen of the country. So, don’t dwell on the vastness of the syllabus but rather concentrate on how to get to know your world a little better.

The Indian Administrative Service is often summarized in the IAS. Or just the IAS, the administrative branch of the All India Services. India's leading civil service is believed, IAS is one of the three arms of All India Services with Indian Police Service (IPS) and Indian Forest Service (IFS). Members of these three services serve the Indian government as well as the individual states. IAS officers can also be deployed in various public sector undertakings. IAS is part of the permanent bureaucracy of the country and is an integral part of the Indian government's executive. Thus, the bureaucracy remains politically neutral and guarantees the administrative continuity to the ruling party. On confirmation of service, an IAS officer serves a probationary period as a sub-divisional magistrate. After completing this probation, an executive administrative role in the district is in the form of a district magistrate and collector, which runs in some states for 16 years for many years. After this tenure, an officer can be promoted as a departmental commissioner for the entire state division. On receiving the top scale, the IAS officers can lead government departments or ministries. In these roles, the IAS officers represent the country in international bilateral and multilateral negotiations. If you serve on deputation, they can be employed in inter-governmental organizations like World Bank, International Monetary Fund, Asian Development Bank, Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, or the United Nations, or its agencies. IAS officers are also included in the conduct of Elections in India essentially by Election Commission of India. Here Is The Difference: Self Study Vs Coaching Going Study If you ask me, what is the best way to prepare for a government sector job like IAS, I will say self-study. Self-study is the most powerful way to gain deep knowledge about any topic. Today many online coaching is available for preparation like Youtube. So you should Start preparing for IAS at home. Let's discuss the topic of how you can do this. Also, I will recommend some best books available in the market. Details About the IAS Exam Distribution of questions, notation planning, sectional loads and duration It is decided every year by the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC). Exam pattern is different for all three stages of IAS (prelims, main, and interview). Here's a brief overview of all of them: IAS Exam Pattern for Prelim- IAS Preliminary Examination includes two Paper General Ability Test (GAT) and Civil Service Attitudes Test (CSAT). Questions will be objective in nature, which will be responsible for a total of 400 marks. IAS prelim is a qualifying round and will not be added to the total score made in the IAS score.IAS test pattern for main cases - There will be two types of papers in the examination - Eligibility letters and papers that will be counted for merit formation. The pre-Part will include two language examinations, the candidate's choice and the other in English. The latter part will have 7 papers and each will have 300 questions. They each have 250 points. The essay writing and objective type in IAS Men will be both questions. In the sum of all the letters and the direct interview, the safe score will be used for the ranking of the candidate.Click To Read How To Start Preparing For IAS At Home-UPSC Preparation Books

To clear IAS Exam, aspirants are advised to have a long-term strategy. Though most of the serious candidates start preparation 9-12 months before the exam date. First things first – understand the UPSC syllabus & pattern Go through previous year test papers to understand the pattern. Multiple sources Every civil services aspirant knows that study material must be sourced from various places but don’t make the mistake of trying to read too many books and end up getting confused and frustrated. Decide on a few books and stick to them. Current affairs Read one o good newspapers to keep yourselves up to date on current affairs. The Hindu or The Indian Express are recommended. Also go through news websites for the latest on topics of national and international politics, science and technology and socio-economic issues. Plans & goals This is clichéd but true. ‘Failing to plan is planning to fail.’ If you want to clear the civil services , you must plan and study. To cover the vast UPSC syllabus, you must plan your day, your week and your month. You ought to have a daily routine where you spend a fixed number of hours to study. Have daily or weekly goals and strive to achieve them. This is the only way to cover the entire syllabus. Revise The importance of revising what you have learned cannot be undermined since it involves being able to recall a lot of facts. This is where making notes come into the picture. With well-made notes, you could revise the whole syllabus. Mock tests Answering previous year question papers can give you an idea of the type of questions asked by the UPSC and also helps you assess your own preparation level well in advance. In addition, you can time your answers optimally. It also helps you know how much time you can spend on each question.Don’t ignore the CSAT( GS paper-2) part,nowadaysyou cannot clear this part just by solving past year 3–4 question papers as suggested by some of them.The level of paper as per trend clearly shows that you need to pay attention to aptitude part as well,atleast last 1 month before prelims. Do not waver Finally, hard work ,consistency and perseverence will help you to achieve your dream. You might be tempted to give up because of the sheer enormity of the task before you. Remember that only claring prelims will not help you to clear upsc,so whenever you start your preparation plan your study with an integrated approach. So buck up, study hard, push yourself to go that extra mile. Do not look at the exams as a burden but as a golden opportunity to improve and showcase your talent and intelligence. Let us sum up the strategy:- Study as per exam patternSource wiselyFocus on current affairsPlanHave goalsRevisePractice test papersHave dedication and passion.

The Union Public Service Commission commonly abbreviated as UPSC, is India's premier central recruiting agency. It is responsible for appointments to and examinations for All India services and group A & group B of Central services.While Department of Personnel and Training is the central personnel agency in India. The agency's charter is granted by Part XIV of the Constitution of India, titled as Services Under the Union and the States. The commission is mandated by the Constitution for appointments to the services of the Union and All India Services. It is also required to be consulted by the Government in matters relating to the appointment, transfer, promotion and disciplinary matters. The commission reports directly to the President and can advise the Government through him. Although, such advice is not binding on the Government. Being a constitutional authority, UPSC is amongst the few institutions which function with both autonomy and freedom, along with the country’s higher judiciary and lately the Election Commission. Go step by step, don’t get confuse or take lots of advice or read blogs unnecessary, believe in your self. You have to be patient, hard working ,be aware of the thing around yourself and increase your curiosity. UPSC is all about enhancing your knowledge, skills and your overall personality. In very simple steps first you have to acquire knowledge then analyse it multidimensionally, you must have your own opinion about a issue or topic and finally you have to present it in your own words in writing and in oral. And believe me you will be in the merit list one day. This is all the UPSC need in all its tiers :: Prelims : your knowledge base Mains : your opinion in writing Interview : reflection of your opinion,stand and knowledge in your overall personality. Knowing or unknowingly if you are working hard and are consistent you will acquire the skill that are needed in bureaucracy. Listing some of them, general awareness and opinion on different issues and general knowledge about history and geography, management of different opinion or tasks simultaneously, empathy, morale upliftment and be a proud Indian. It may not be original sometimes but you have /will acquire it subsequently to fit in Indian Bureaucracy and that is what the selection process of UPSC does to the aspirants. I have been preparing for the services and I have read various answers in quora to the same question. They discuss various strategy and book list and to my belief they are cent percent right. Therefore I will not be repeating those again in my answer but I ll discuss some basic tenants that I feel are necessary. For static portion read NCERT and basic standard books. Read one book many times, don’t go for every book mentioned in the list. Choose your weapon and sharp it again and again and again :) .For dynamic portion read one newspaper, analyse it , see some editorial discussion videos on youtube after reading it beforehand. Refer some magazines or RSTV Debates on topics/ issues you feel important.Practice previous year papers and the syllabus should be very clear to you.Write answers everyday. Actual preparation starts from the day you start writing an essay or answer or short notes on issue or topics on routine basis. Before it , it is all time-pass or in proper words just a warm up.Make short notes to revise. AS short and simple as you can so that the whole topic/ issue is revised in the least time possible.At last be very consistent, patient it takes time and sweat. And most importantly believe and appreciate whatever you study, it will retain. Hope I have answered the query satisfactorily. Sorry for any grammatical mistakes, I did’nt had time to check it. Thank for reading!!

UPSC is one such examination which not only checks how diverse your knowledge is or how in depth you know the things but also ensures that every candidate develops a multi-dimensional character.When it comes to preparation, consistency and patience is one such thing which helps an aspirant to sail through this exam. There are various methods used by aspirants to manage their consistency level. These may be; A strong reason:- Every aspirant possesses a personal reason that why he wants to crack this exam which motivates him/her to clear the same. The reason can vary. For some it may be power, perks,fame or money and for other it may be their parent’s wish and service to the nation. This makes them consistent and patient.There comes a point in the life of every aspirant when panic and fear of failure haunts them but then there is a much stronger reason to supress all these negative vibes and gives them the required energy to get back to their work. I have met some of the aspirants and when I asked them the Same question, they replied that they sometimes listen motivational songs which acts like a recharge fuel and gives them the required power to continue. Since the examination almost takes a year for completion, it becomes obvious to become consistent and patient and this is what UPSC is all about. Good luck.

Hello, UPSC is the toughest exam with the huge syllabus so if you are having a problem in concentrating then don't worry as its normal. But if you cannot concentrate continuously then the problem starts, so its the time to get motivated by watching all the videos of the toppers and know what were their struggles and how they successfully broke it and now they are the ias officers of India. you should always spend some quality time alone and do whatever makes you happy because it will energize you and make you fit and ready to study again with 100% dedication and concentration. You can even listen to music, take a nap, or just relax …these will be helpful to bring back the consistency in your preparations. Good Luck !

I presume you have enough time. No general strategy is applicable to all. There are three essential requirements; good in academics, good in general awareness and good in language , that is , communication. The last two are long term investments. So one can start building them from undergraduate level. Cultivate good habits. Determination and perseverance are critical, keep your motivation high. Keep good company and avoid time wasting activity . Do take time out for relaxation but limit this. I presume that you are still studying. So, focus on your studies but earmark some time for language and general awareness. Follow time management skills. One of basics for this to devide the time into quantas, which I call periods, consisting of 30 minutes each. Assess the optimum time available to you for them. You should be able to manage at least 10–15 periods a week in addition to your studies. Now make a plan. Keep separate note books for each and take notes. For language, read good prose, anything that interests you. My favourites in entertainment, were Agatha Christie and Wodehouse and Graham Greene , Aldous Huxley, and Bertrand Russell for serious reading. Focus on vocabulary and usage. Write regularly, anything that you fancy, letters, diary or articles. For general studies , during this period and later, read at least one good newspaper and one news magazine . Read the op-ed page regularly. Keep track of current trends in science and technology and economic developments. Full time preparation should start about a year in advance. About 3000–3500 hours of time is required. You will get a lot of guidance in this from professionals and amateurs. Most people join coaching classes. Choose wisely, if you do. In general, time management is important. Take care of your health.

I want to work for respect rather than money. We are the farmers, hence we don’t have the greed of money.I want to work for the people not because of the people.I want satisfaction over the competition & facilities.As I’m from a rural background, I have seen all the problems, difficulties, disappointments, poverty, suicides, violence, lack of education, etc. issues, which face the people at the ground level. Hence, decided to prepare UPSC to make a better life for these people.My father has given me one value, which is loyalty. He is a farmer and working hard for me to support my career. I have seen him while working hard which motivate me to achieve my goals.My mother has taught me to stay focused on your work. No matter if people will appreciate you or not.My parents don’t have enough money to buy something for them. But they always say ‘Just focus on your career we will do anything, we will take a loan, we will do more hard work to give you the money.’And it is not the ending list I have hundreds of other reasons.

I yet to come across a recommended preparation strategy for UPSC CSE. Many so called strategies are floating all around. They are all untested, imaginative, and money centric. Each successful candidate had his or her own approach to CSE. They have arrived at that winning formula through trial and error, testing and retesting, etc. Civils exam is a highly “individual centric” exam. Each candidate has to devise his or her own approach to this exam. NO coaching centre in India will be able to suggest or recommend you a preparation strategy. If any coaching centre suggests a strategy and claims it will help you to succeed, believe me, they are making huge money by conning you. Coaching centers, at best, help in flagging some relevant issues in a given subject and may provide some relevant material on these issues. Upto that point, there won't be much problem. If you are offered a preparation strategy by these coaches or coaching centers, they are making you a sissy. Don't allow it. UPSC thinking and reach is on a different plane. No coaching centre in India will ever be able to break into to “thinking” of UPSC. UPSC is far far ahead of all the coaching centers put together. CSE is a highly individual centric examination. Acquire basic knowledge in relevant subjects. Read and understand upsc previous questions. Write your own answers to questions. Reduce reading. Practice writing and writing and writing. Workout your own winning formula. Enforce rigorous self discipline. Your name will figure in the final select list.

College students find themselves in a tight spot when it comes to preparing for civil services examination and career counsellors receive an avalanche of mails regarding best preparation strategy to start early. We all are well-aware of the adage "The early bird catches the worm". Early birds are persons who embark on desired actions to achieve their target much earlier than others and indeed early birds are winners in all walks of life, and the same is true with regard to Civil Services Exam as well. This article will shed a light on all the possible strategies to get through the Civil Services examination at the earliest.  Start early to save precious youth-years! As we all know, the syllabus of Civil Services Exam is vast and time is limited, so it's prudent to start preparation as early as possible. This does not imply that if a school student longs to become an IAS officer, he should commence his preparation with heavy-weight UPSC books right from class 4, but an approach in tune with UPSC requirements will certainly help. Adopting a long term approach has proven to be effective and also saves previous youth-years of many candidates. As an early bird, you will be better equipped and oriented when you actually wet your feet in the UPSC waters.  But that doesn't mean that those who start late can't clear the IAS exam! This does not imply that those who start late are at fault and cannot clear the exam. All it requires is perseverance and a fervent desire to get through the Civil Services Examination. With iron will and right approach, a junior can come up with flying colors. This article intends to convey that early starters can be at the advantageous position provided that they keep the same vigour till the end. How much time is needed for IAS preparation? We all know haste makes waste and perseverance is the key to success. This eternal principal also holds true when it comes to the preparation for Civil Services Examination. The analytical ability, knowledge and personality of the candidate developed within a span of 20 years are tested in this exam. For building a strong foundation, long-term effort is required; however the foundation can be polished according to the UPSC requirement in the last one year. So, an aspirant should strive hard to build a strong foundation. If you have built a strong foundation, the job is half done. A stark naked, but motivating truth: If you have a habit of reading newspapers regularly and a good grasp on the subjects in your school days (NCERT books), you are as good as most of the serous and senior players taking this exam. All successful candidates have a decent newspaper reading habit and exceptional command over subjects in their school days. I have enough time; what should be my strategy to clear IAS in the first attempt? The average UPSC aspirant's mind keeps on bristling with numerous questions like: How to manage UPSC preparation during my preparation?How to begin IAS preparation?As a beginner how should I start Civil Services exam preparation?Answers to all the queries are below listed five suggestions: 1. A good understanding of the UPSC exam structure is vital and without it your preparation will go in the wrong direction. Going through UPSC syllabus and previous year question papers of Mains as well as IAS Prelims will help you understand the areas from which questions are normally asked. 2. Needless to say, newspaper reading habit is vitally important. Experts advise reading The Indian Express or The Hindu. 3. All Civil Services Examination aspirants are well attuned to the importance of reading NCERT books. Priority should be given to geography, history, economy and polity related NCERT texts. So what does that mean for school students? As a student, get the hang of school texts, it will lay the foundation for your success in UPSC examination. Think and chew over what is mentioned in your textbooks. Good writing skills are mandatory for UPSC aspirants as the best of your efforts will fall through in dearth of enough writing practice. 4. College going students and pass outs should decide on the optional subject after analysing previous year question papers and UPSC syllabus and start collecting relevant materials on the same. Aspirants should try to finish optional subject first, as this will definitely give you an edge. 5. During leisure time, go through the books related to India written by eminent authors. Reading these books will provide a clear picture of the past, present and future of India besides widening your horizon. A good understanding of the problems of India with their right solutions can immensely help you frame answers in Civil Services Mains, Essay paper and General Studies.

The steps to start UPSC preparation are as follows: 1. Know the exam dates Before you preparing for the UPSC civil services examination you should know about the important dates. UPSC release the calendar one year prior with all important dates. The aspirants have to check this calendar to know about the examination. The first step in figuring out how to start preparation for civil services exam is to know the exam. 2. Make a time table To become an IAS officer, it is necessary to be like an officer with a well-organized daily routine. Aspirants should set a comfortable timetable before your preparation and act accordingly to the same. Making timetable will ease your preparation and transform you into an organized person. This is considered as an essential quality of an officer. 3. Newspaper Reading The current affairs gained a crucial role in Civil Services IAS Examination. In fact, the UPSC conduct this examination does not check the level of candidate’s knowledge. It wants to check the officer like quality with sufficient general knowledge. Before starting preparation, aspirants should choose and read an English Newspaper daily. The best option is The Hindu and Indian express. Aspirants should be able to recognize the relevant news. Once you are thorough with your syllabus you will be able to pick out the relevant news and articles from the newspaper. The aspirant can avoid the film columns, gossip column, sports, political news etc. one should not leave the editorials and the special articles related to subjects. Along with this one has to prepare short notes on the topic to wise using you pragmatic mind, prudence and with the flavor of common sense. 4. Choosing Optional The optional subject plays very significant role in the aspirant’s overall mark of the exam. There are numerous facets which enable the aspirants to choose a particular optional subject. One should choose a comfortable and favorite subject as optional. Devote time for optional with relevant sources of books. While choosing optional one has to be careful. The present pattern has reduced the number of optional subjects to be selected to one comprising of two papers of 250 marks each. 5. Know the UPSC Syllabus What to study for UPSC Exam?/What to study for IAS exam? The syllabus is the soul of any exam. If you know the soul you conquer the examination easily. Knowing the syllabus is the basic and foremost thing to do before you go through the book. The UPSC has provided the syllabus for Civil Services Preliminary and Main examination in an elaborative manner. Aspirants should understand and follow the syllabus for UPSC civil service examination. Knowing the syllabus will help you to choose relevant study materials, prioritize the subjects etc. 6. NCERT book and other detailed reference books The NCERT from Class six to twelve plays a very significant role in UPSC Civil service IAS examination preparation. Aspirants can get basic concepts and theories from NCERT textbooks. These books provide the information very coherently. In previous years UPSC has asked questions directly from NCERT textbooks. It also helps to imbibe the core concepts in Economics and Polity. NCERT also provides the authentic study material for the Indian History. The aspirant should make a list of the essential NCERT books and detailed reference books. One can choose the books either a hard copy or soft copy. While reading and studying NCERT don’t to make a short note which can be used for revision. The most repeated answer to the question, ‘How to prepare for UPSC exam?’ would be to read NCERT books. 7. Make Short notes It is very vital to make short notes during UPSC preparation, especially in the context of Civil service main examination. One cannot expect to gain success in Main examination without intensive study and without preparing own notes and revising them regularly. So, it is essential to write down what you understand in your own words. Re-writing the information from the source does not help you in the examination. Aspirants should make short notes for each subject, NCERT, newspaper editorial and current affairs. 8. Answer writing Practice The IAS Civil Services main examination is descriptive in nature. It is mainly about testing the candidate’s analytical, critical, and communicative abilities. It demands the candidate to think with conceptual clarity and organizes their view, perception, thoughts in a flawless manner. An essential thing to be kept in mind is the time constraint. Therefore candidates have to answer the questions quickly and effectively and in minimum words. Without practicing one cannot able to write perfect answers within the limited time. So it is essential to write an answer daily. This will enhance the answer writing skill of students. 9. Solving and Practicing Previous Years Question Paper Previous Years Question papers are the most genuine source of information for both prelims and main examination. One of the key nuts and bolts of the Civil Service Examination preparations is practicing previous years question papers and sample papers. Solving previous years question paper will help you to understand the pattern and enhance your revision. Once you revise the previous years question papers, you will get to know about the mode and the mixture of easy and complex questions and master the knack of balancing to maximize scores which eventually matter. However, candidates should remember that the previous years papers do not mean the question papers of last 10-20 years. Take the paper, solely since the syllabus and format of the examination has modified otherwise you may find yourself wasting an excessive amount of time. 10. Important government resources The other important sources for UPSC IAS Exam are the government websites like pib, prs, Television programmes like Rajya Sabha debate etc. The aspirant should watch these debates and surf through these websites to get a wide aspect about government programmes. This will help you to build your own perspective. 11. Relevant magazines Reading an authentic book does not mean you need to extract the whole essence of the book. Pick out the relevant information needed for UPSC examination with the help of syllabus. Aspirants should subscribe magazines like Kurukshetra, Yojana, and Frontline for further reading. Reading the relevant government magazines will also help you to prepare in better manner. 12. Healthy discussions Group discussion with friends those who are preparing for the same examination. This will help you to expand the horizon of knowledge. Such discussions will also give you new ideas on how to start studying for IAS exam. 13. Wise and effective use of social media Use the social media platform and internet effectively for your preparation. Social media can also give a lot of tips on how to prepare IAS at home. 14. Revision Mostly the revision is done in last months of examination. But UPSC demands a daily revision. Daily morning one should go through your short notes which you have prepared already during your preparation. If you have studied sincerely, you should not need over fifteen minutes going through your notes. The very last month of the exam is not an ideal time to aggregate more data. During revision, if you come across something which you do not remember, simply push you forward and don’t get panic. The regular revision will retain your memory power. 15. Mock test series Self-assessment is an essential part of UPSC preparation. It can help civil service aspirant in realizing and learning from mistakes, shaping what approach they need to be followed in continuing the preparation and identifying strengths and weaknesses. It is highly recommended to join mock test series especially when you are preparing from home. This will help you to assess yourself and help you further. Always remember below lines of sir Abdul Kalam  ALL THE BEST!!!

Hi This is one of the most basic questions every aspirant has in his mind! Quite existential also, right HOW! What surprises me the most, though, is nobody asks WHY! I mean, at least I feel that if you don’t have an answer to the WHY here, you will never be able to apply the answers of HOW to your life! Before asking this question, ask WHY DO I WANT TO PREPARE FOR UPSC? And find the most convincing answer, not for anybody else, but for yourself! And mind you, it shouldn’t be because “papa ne bola, mummy ne bola, or sharma ji ka beta bhi IAS hai”! Because, to be honest, none of that is going to help you in sustaining the pressure that comes with the preparation of an exam as demanding as UPSC CSE! It should come from within, you should want that life for yourself, you should feel that you belong there and this exam is the path to reach there, then and only then, you will be able to put the answers of HOW to reality! So, once you’ve figured out the WHY part, so many wonderful people have answered the how-part for you! Just take inspiration from any one of them and come up with your own strategy! Remember, it is never the borrowed dream that you can carry and never the borrowed strategy that can work wonders for you! So, take inspiration from all the answers and come up with your own strategy, that will work the best for you! All the best

Hi guys, here i am going to tell you about the preparat ion for UPSC exam. The Civil Services exam is the doorway to exciting careers in the Indian Administrative Service (IAS), Indian Foreign Service (IFS), Indian Revenue Service (IRS), Indian Police Service (IPS) and more. With lakhs of people attempting the elite services examination and only a few hundred seats typically available, the competition is fierce. To beat the competition, it’s important to prepare thoroughly and give yourself the maximum chance of success. The Civil Services exam takes place in 3 stages preliminary exam (Prelims) consisting of objective-type multiple choice questions, the mains exam which is an essay-type written exam, and a personal interview. The 3 stages are separated by a gap of 1-2 months. Given below are some major UPSC Preparation Tips which a candidate can follow to score high in the exam: Mock Test Papers or UPSC Question Papers:Mock Papers are an essential part of regular preparations for successful candidates.Writing mock tests not only helps you to revise your IAS Syllabus but also helps to increase your speed to solve the exam in time. There is always a crunch of time in IAS Exam, one has to be very fast in writing questions. Mock test papers help in increasing the speed of mind to make calculations. 2.Right Choice of IAS Preparatory Books: It is of utmost importance to pick up only recommended books and the right study material for IAS Preparation. NCERT books are always highly suggested and are considered as a must-read by experts as well as successful candidates, clear up doubts at a fundamental level and help candidates in scoring higher scores at IAS Main level. Although there are a number of books available for IAS in the market one needs to select only the best out of them and should prepare for only a few best ones. 3.GS Paper 1 is the key: Deep study of every subject: Till 2014, scoring high in GS Paper 2 was the easiest way to clear UPSC mains. Putting less effort as compared to GS Paper I, aspirants used to score high and clear prelims. On the basic level, covering every subject of the UPSC main exam is the best approach to clear the Prelims test. It's not recommended to give priority to any particular book or area thinking that questions will come from that source. Likewise, one must not miss the easy questions from traditional subjects like Polity, History, Geography, History, and Economics. Current affairs are also important to prepare as they are definitely asked, other than that latest schemes and bills launched by the government are also valuable. 4.IAS Prelims cum IAS Main Approach: Even though the type of questions asked in UPSC Prelims and Main are different, but there are also many areas where one can find some kind of similarity in the questions. For GS Paper I, an ideal strategy suggests covering GS Main and Prelims syllabus in detail first that gives the concept clarity about all major topics. 5.Time Management: All you need to do is to manage your time in a way that you can easily cover your decided syllabus and gets proper rest and sleep at the same time. One must note that you do not need books or notes on bulk to completely go through but only a limited no. of good books and a deep study of that study material. It is very must important for a student to get proper rest and sleep. 6.Mental Peace is the key: All your efforts and hard work go in vain if you lose your cool on the peace of mind, otherwise you get confused and selects the wrong answer and even takes more time in solving a question then what is actually needed. So at last you need a peaceful ful mind from upsc preparation till exam. Above some tips is to crack UPSC exam. For more information about Upsc, you can visit the website Mypustak. In this website you get more and information and you also get books for preparation here at free of cost. You no need to charge for that books. So visit the website now for more books and information about any exam. Thank you..

A famous saying goes like: “If you fail to plan, you plan to fail” This is even more relevant for people, who are preparing for UPSC Civil Services Examination (CSE). Frankly speaking, if you don't plan your strategy and preparation in advance, this UPSC CSE is such a massive vortex of innumerable factors and uncertaininity that leave alone getting taste of success, you won't even be able to find out reasons of your failure. Long story short, Planning is important- both at macro (weekly and monthly) and micro(daily) levels. However, the elephant in the room is - ‘how to do it!’ First of all, being organised is important. Having a definitive daily-routine would help you to implement your daily targets. Here is a sample of a daily routine of a sincere UPSC CSE aspirant. First, Newspaper reading ( may be 45 mins- 1.30 hr depending on how long you have been in the preparation) Second, any topic in GS Paper 1 ( for example: Modern Indian History, Art and Culture, etc. ( 3 hours session with 1–2 short breaks) Third, Optional paper ( Topic and Paperwise, 4 hours with 2–3 short breaks) Fourth, again any topic in GS paper-2 ( For example: Constitutional underpinnings, Indian Parliament, etc. Fifth, revise the Notes of Current affairs that you had made previous day during newspaper reading Sixth, 20 minutes Daily Answer Writing ( 2–3 questions) Now, you can call it a day. Total estimated hours of study : 8–11 hours For some people who will find it overwhelming to study for such long period on daily basis, remember,  All the best,

UPSC exam is the most prestigious exam in India. Before you prepare for the UPSC exam you need to have the willpower and the dedication for the exam. Before you starts the preparation you have to know the syllabus, because without knowing the exam pattern you can not succeed any exam. The Civil Services Examination is conducted in 3 stages. The entire process takes almost an year: Stage I - Preliminary Examination (usually conducted in May/June, results by August) Stage II - Main Examination (usually conducted around November, results by February/March) Stage III - Interview (usually conducted over Marc/April, final results announced a few days before the next preliminary exam) (For details visit UPSC official website.) 2 preparations are required Preparation mentally that you have to be committed and dedicated for min 365 days.subject preparationUnder Subject preparation: a) Learning content b) Presenting Content Learning content happens in 3 phases: a) Conceptual Understanding b) Application development c) Updating the latest developments in the application.(Like how we update the software of our mobile, same way we need to do to our content) Step 1: Understand the syllabus(DON’T MUG UP THE SYLLABUS. Toppers suggest to mug up but actually you shouldn’t do that) Instead understand the syllabus. Map the syllabus in NCERT, reference books. Step 2: Start concept preparation by using NCERT’s. NCERT helps you to learn concepts which helps you to learn reference books. Step 3: Along with NCERT go through news paper simultaneously. Try to identify the important articles or relevant news by using the syllabus and NCERT. Step 4: Start applying the concepts you learnt in your day to day affairs which you go through the newspaper. Step 5: Now start writing answers every day . You dont need advanced questions. To build your confidence start writing questions mentioned in NCERT books. Later you can practice advanced questions. Step 6: Move slowly to advanced learning by going through needed and relevant reference books only. Link the basic concepts to the advanced learning. Step 7: For up-dation of your content use Economic Survey, Budget, Government reports. Good luck!!!

Before starting to prepare for UPSC, keep in mind the reason (a genuine one) for which you want to clear this exam. Because the syllabus is so vast that you'll need a strong reason which will force you to prepare well for the exam. If you don't have any strong reason then stop reading further. If you got the perfect reason then you must start reading NCERT books from 6th to 12th std. They are the base of your preparation. Make sure to complete these books as early as possible. So that you'll have enough time to read and revise standard books. Don't look for shortcuts. UPSC doesn't expect you to complete 100% syllabus but expects 100% accuracy in what you know. Give at least a year for the preparation. Also keep yourself updated with current affairs and new policies. Even after all this if you fail, then don't worry and give it another try for sake of your “STRONG REASON" which I mentioned above (got my point of having strong reason?). I hope this will help you boost your confidence. Keep Learning n sharing! All the best.

The Civil Services exam is the doorway to exciting careers in the Indian Administrative Service (IAS), Indian Foreign Service (IFS), Indian Revenue Service (IRS), Indian Police Service (IPS) and more. With lakhs of people attempting the elite services examination and only a few hundred seats typically available, the competition is fierce. To beat the competition, it’s important to prepare thoroughly and give yourself the maximum chance of success. The Civil Services exam takes place in 3 stages; preliminary exam (Prelims) consisting of objective-type multiple choice questions, the main examwhich is an essay-type written exam, and a personal interview. The 3 stages are separated by a gap of 1-2 months. When Is The Right Time To Start Preparing For Civil Services? Some aspirants begin preparing for the Civil Services directly from high school and others start studying only 7 months before the exams. The ideal time to start preparing is in the last few years of your graduation degree as you can attempt the exam only once you graduate. How To Begin Your UPSC Preparation You have the conviction, you have the passion and a career in Civil Service is your goal. Now, comes the path to your goal. To begin your preparation for the Civil Services Exam, start reading NCERT books for Political Science, History, Economics and Geography from Class 6-10 levels, based on the Civil Services official syllabus. Additionally, you may utilise reference books. A few good ones for Prelims are: History India’s Ancient Past by R. S. SharmaHistory of Medieval India by Satish ChandraHistory of Modern India by Bipan ChandraIndia’s Struggle For Independence by Bipan ChandraGeography Geography of India by Majid HusainOxford School AtlasEconomics Indian Economy by Ramesh SinghPolitical Science Indian Polity by M. LakshmikanthGet in the habit of thoroughly reading newspapers on a daily basis, for at least 2-3 hours, and compare the current events with theoretical knowledge studied in Political Science, History, Geography and Economics. Prepare personalized notes, focusing on your weak points and how you remember things best. Take help of all the resources in your power, whether it’s aid from former teachers, online videos, guidebooks, and coaching centres. Be sure to use your time wisely, study with full concentration and test yourself at each step of the way. Make revision your best friend and be confident in your abilities. I’ll talk about the specific preparation for each of the 3 UPSC stages in the coming sections. Let’s talk about two other pressing concerns first.

First step: Learn the requirements of the UPSC Civil Services Exam! No. You don’t need to know everything under the Sun to clear this exam. That’s the first thing to get into your head. There is a prescribed syllabus by UPSC for the three stages of this 1-year long exam, i.e Prelims, Mains and Interview. A good understanding of UPSC Syllabus and exam pattern is the first step for all freshers. Also, understand the Eligibility criteria for writing UPSC exam. Second Step: Buy some essential books to get the stone rolling: Everyone will agree that without investing in some books, one cannot clear IAS exam. That’s right. The syllabus is vast, the aspirant should develop the habit of reading. To start with, we recommend buying some useful books (like Indian Polity by Laxmikanth) in addition to all the NCERT books. List of essential books for IAS preparation is compiled in this website, taking inputs from many toppers. Links are also provided to buy online at discounted prices. Order a few basic books on the list today itself, so that you will feel that you are into it. Also, make newspaper reading a habit. Third Step: Read our free online study materials: Yes; there is such thing as a free lunch. We call it free online study materials from Clear IAS™. We write articles regularly on many topics – basically on those which aspirants find it tough to find the right materials. We publish study materials for every subject in Prelims and Mains like History, Geography, Economics, Polity, Current Affairs etc and ensure that the contents help in quick learning. Fourth Step: Get the right guidance; follow our articles on UPSC Civil Services Exam guidance: Requirements for each stage of the UPSC exam, i.e Prelims, Mains and Interview are different. But there are many things in common too. Hence, Clear IAS - UPSC Civil Services Free Online Coaching Website throughout this website follows Prelims-cum-Mains Integrated approach, which is a fast and smooth approach to clear IAS. Fifth Step: Join Clear IAS mock test series: practice, learn, and revise: You can learn and compete with thousands of aspirants across India by attempting our full length timed online mock test series with negative marking for UPSC Prelims. Always keep in touch with UPSC previous year question papers so that you won’t read wild things, and stay focused. Seventh Step: Stop worrying too much; just do it: Well, why don’t do get your feet wet? You have nothing to lose. But you will be a totally different person, well aware of our nation and things around you once you step in. Don’t worry about your age, financial background, lack of time or any other usual excuses. You are never late. Get involved. Just jump in and do it! Understand that a journey of thousand miles starts with a single step.

1. First choose your optional subject: Score in your Optional decides whether you will qualify or not. So choose and prepare Optional first since it is a static subject (syllabus does not change much). 2. For optional One can take coaching since it is bit technical. Buy the best available notes of Optional subject. Buy a previous year question paper book of optional and practice questions. 70–80% previous year questions are repeated in optional. If you prepare the optional well, then your chance to qualify become 70%. 3. Then go for General studies like History, Geography, Polity. Coaching one may take or may not. If you can not afford coaching go through the free videos available on Mrunal, Unacademy, insightonIndia. Booklist: one should know what to read and what not to read. This saves a lot of time and energy. 4. Notes: Always make notes. Evernote or paper note anything you can do. But make notes. Systematic notes so that you can revise. Give mock tests. There is a secret to crack all exams. 5. Prepare → Give mock test → See your weakness → Work on it → Give more mock test. Giving mock tests, evaluating your preparation and working on it can make you crack any exam. 6. Current affairs: There is a way to read news paper. One has to link it with Static part through forward and backward linkage. For that one has to have a strong base on statics. 7. Emotionally strong: An average student takes around 2–3 years to clear this exam. Not less even those who says I cleared it in first attempt too. Are you willing to sit and study for 8–9 hours daily for 2–3 years with only one goal? If you are that determined then you can clear this exam. Thanks for Reading 😊

UPSC being the toughest exam in the country, requires more than just preparation. It requires both strategy and preparation. UPSC exam consists of 3 stages: preliminary exam (objective)main exam (subjective)InterviewNow the most important question as to how to prepare for UPSC: First, go through the syllabus as it will help you in understanding what to read and what not to. The questions asked in the exam are always within the syllabus and hence keeping a close eye on syllabus is fundamental. Second, choose your study material wisely and the best source to get clarity and a good hold on various subjects are the NCERT books (from class VI to class XII). Third, Time management is important so don’t waste your time too much if you are not understanding a topic instead go to YouTube and watch the videos of that particular topic. For math watch the videos of EXADEMY[1] they explain each and every topic in detail and are quick to clear your doubts if you have any or you can watch their live classes with affordable fees ( my friend got herself enrolled in EXADEMY and where ever she goes she always gives good reviews and recommends people to watch their videos). Fourth, stay updated with what is going around in the world. Watch news channels( like NDTV and not news like times now, Republic tv), many people would say to read newspapers but I would recommend you to read magazines instead or watch STUD talks of EXADEMY( it is basically a talk session on various issues and happenings in the country) so you can give importance to other subjects as well, many toppers of UPSC don’t read newspapers as it consumes a lot of time. Fifth, keeping giving mock tests and analyze where you are going wrong. Give 2- 3 mock papers in a week the more you test yourself the more you will gain confidence, and get familiar with the pattern. Last, but not the least, is proper care your health. One must exercise or take a walk, to remain healthy, as well as maintain higher concentration during study hours. All the very best for your UPSC exam. Footnotes[1] https://www.exademy.in/

Here are the correct strategy for preparing for UPSC, the most toughest exam in india. Now let start the strategy points: As we all know the fact that revision is significantly important before jumping to the next topics, revision must be given utmost importance in the process of preparation. It's time for students to get a good hold on the topics they have studied. Here are few revision tips that can indeed help students notch up success in the examination: 1. Revise at least twice before exam: Map out your studies in a way so that adequate time is left for revision. It is equally important that no topic should be skipped while revising. Revise everything. 2. Basics have to be strong: Having a strong command over the basics is better than just knowing the entire subject. Numerous questions are asked from subjects like current affairs, Indian history, Geography, Indian Polity, Ecology, Biodiversity and Environment, hence they should be prepared in detail. Candidates tend to ignore prelims because the questions are objective in nature, but the questions are tricky and each question aims to check the knowledge of students in depth, and therefore, equal importance has to be given to the preliminary examination. 3. Solve mock test papers: Solving previous years' question papers zeroes out chances of errors in the examination and increases accuracy and speed. It provides the opportunity to get the hang of time management and have a clear idea of the paper. Accordingly, you can decide which section has to be attempted first. 4. Prepare notes: Notes help to revise concepts quickly when a candidate wrestles with time; so, it is advisable to prepare notes especially on topics which are tough for you. Making notes help you remember things in a better way. 5. Get familiarise with syllabus: Getting well attuned to the syllabus is the first step to set about systematic preparation. It provides the right direction to your preparation and helps you stave off covering irrelevant topics. 6. Selection of books: Most of the candidates get perplexed referring to countless books available in the market. Make your basics strong with NCERT books and count on standard book to farther go through relevant topics. 7. Strategise: General studies paper covers everything. It can be categorised as: Geography: Focus on physical geography and maps. Atlas is the best guide to help you with these topicsGeneral awareness: This embraces government schemes etc. Reading newspapers and guidebooks will help you a great dealHistory: Emphasise on Modern history, Freedom movement, Ancient India etc. A standard history guide covers all these topicsCurrent Affairs: Going through at least two standard newspapers (one English and the other, a vernacular) will keep you abreast of the current eventsCSAT: It covers a vast portion. Comprehension, logical reasoning, basic numeracy are to be prepared from standard book8. New topic: Don't read any new topic prior to the examination. 9. Proper sleep: All the students should note that sleep deprivation will take you nowhere; so, sleep well on the eve of the examination and don't go through any book. 10. Confidence: Note that confidence is the key to success in any examination so be high on confidence and do not panic during examination. Remember one thing ,you can do it. THANKS FOR READING. HAVE A GREAT FUTURE :) By Noman Ahmed.

UPSC exams requires proper planning, systematic preparation and appropriate resource materials. # Read Syllabus # Identify and select Resource materials For Civil Services Examination, different strategies have to adopted for preparing for Prelims, Main and Interview. In fact for preparing the IAS / CSE Prelims, one may begin with reading of 10 / 11 / 12th standard NCERT / CBSE / State Board Book and 2–3 Newspapers. Browsing the Internet for current affairs would also be helpful. A thorough knowledge of concepts, current affairs, speed and accuracy coupled with confidence would be key elements to tackle Prelims. Key Elements of Strategy* Time management* Appropriate Topic wise Action / Study Plan The following are suggested for the preparation of Prelims - I Reading of Resource materials: Plus 2 level books (NCERT / CBSE / State Board Books) – Biology, Chemistry NCERT / CBSE Books for 10th - for humanities, Science and chapters relevant for General studies. NCERT / CBSE Books for 11th& 12th NCERT Books for 10th on Polity, Economy, Geography and History Current Affairs: @ Daily Newspapers, online reading of current national / international events. @ Any Good comprehensive General Knowledge Book – latest edition. @ Browse current affairs relevant topics / articles on net / good magazines.

Things you must know before you start preparing for UPSC civil services examination…. EXAM DATE ; The exam dates are subject to change as per the UPSC guidelines. So, you must know required to keep an eye on the new dates released by the commission on official website.THE SUBSET OF SERVICES ; IPS, IRS, IFS fall under the services of the CSE and the cutoff to get recruited in the services mentioned above is decided after the conduction of the exam. A good understanding of the target is what will streamline the preparation and to keep the focused better.PREPARATION TECHNIQUE ; It is not fact that CSE is the nation's toughest competitive exam . There is no definite answer to the most commonly asked questions, such as how many hours an CSE person need to put in every day? It will differ from person to person so let us look at it from a general perspective.TIME REQUIRED : Many Experts believe that aggressive preparation for 10 to 12 months is must. Ideally you should target two subjects every day. as most of the questions are asked mostly from Class 6 to 12 standard books. So preparing notes and devoting 10 to 12 hours before a year of exam is believed to be sufficient.

If you have decided to prepare for the UPSC exam then let me congratulate you first. Because this preparation is going to be a wonderful experience in your life. Preparation strategy. 1-Take out the UPSC syllabus,read it and try to understand it. 2-Take previous years'question papers and see how the questions were asked(both for Prelims as well as Mains). 3-Read the basic NCERT'S of Geography, History, Environment,Polity, Economics, Science.(Std 6 to 12′th are considered as basic NCERT'S). These books will give complete idea of that subjects in a easy way. 4-Keep referring syllabus and previous years’ question papers while reading NCERT. 5-When you will complete reading either subject's NCERT. Let us assume that you have completed reading Indian Polity's NCERT then go for it's standard reference book like Indian Polity by M.Laxmikanth. 6-Read atleast one news paper like The Hindu,The Indian Express.. 7-You can also join coaching classes if you need. Coaching classes will not ensure your selection but coaching will make things somewhat easier and will also help in solving your doubts. There are many students which were selected without joining any coaching classes so it is not mandatory. 8-Try to read only reference books rather referring any local class notes or local books. Keep it to only one reference book for one subject.(In some case you may have to go for another reference book.) This is for initial stage of preparation.All the Best..!!

The Key to clear any exam is to be DETERMINED,FOCUSSED and SELF- ANALYTICAL. UPSC Exam is also no different. UPSC Exam consists of 3 exams-PRELIMS, MAINS and INTERVIEW. I am sharing my preparation strategy. I started preparing one year before attempting Prelims. I made a time –table which I strictly followed no matter what. I am sharing time –table https://www.quora.com/What-is-your-daily-routine-or-how-do-did-you-manage-your-daily-time-for-UPSC-preparation/answer/Bornali-Das-15 I made monthly, weekly and daily target for studies. PRELIMS STRATEGY Preparation Guide Smart study + Daily revision+ Solving Mcqs regularly = Key to success in CSE Studying too many books is nothing but waste of time which leads to failure” I studied very selectively. I did not read books cover to cover, instead made crisp notes for revision. I took three months to cover prelims syllabus. Revise, revise and revise. This is the philosophy I followed. I am sharing my Prelims Booklist Booklist – 1. Polity – Laxmikanth 2. Culture – Nitin Singhania Notes 3. History – Spectrum Modern India 4. Economics – NCERTS( Macro Economics & Economic Development),Indian Economy by Ramesh Singh ,Economic survey,Govt Schemes,Etc 5. Geography – NCERTS Class 11 & 12 6. Environment – Shankar IAS 7. Current Affairs –Hindu and monthly magazines 8. Vishals Publications Prelims Solved Papers 1995 to 2018. I practiced atleast 40–45 tests for Prelims .One can opt for any good test series The more one practices MCQs,the more is his chances of clearing the exam. MAINS STRATEGY Read-Make Notes-Revise-Write Answers- Revise Optional: I took coaching from Upendra Gaur Sir for Sociology . Optional is the most scorable in Mains CSE I compiled books and coaching class materials and made one precise notes which was very easy to revise. Once done, I revised those notes thoroughly and started writing answers. First I attempted previous year’s paper and then regular mock tests. I revised Optional 5 times. ESSAY Paper: Next most scoring paper is Essay. I Practise essay writing in an organised manner within a stipulated time. I refered can refer Shubhra Ranjan Mam’s Essay Book. Adding Quotes also helped me in getting a good score. ETHICS: I refered LEXICON and practice many case studies everyday atleast one. GS-1, 2 & 3 I made notes for each topics mentioned in the syllabus. CURRENT AFFAIRS I made notes and revised them properly. Last but not the least to clear Mains it is mandatory to practise answer writing and get it evaluated by any faculty or Mentor.

The IAS exams conducted by the UPSC is one of the most difficult and coveted exam of the country. Lakhs of Aspirants give it and a few succeed it. The minimum age for taking the exams is 21 and maximum age is 32 years. Any graduate or those appearing in the final stream of graduation can apply for the exams. The IAS exams consists of 3 stages: prelims where objective type questions are asked from GS subjects like history,geography, polity etc and CSAT section . Those who qualify prelims are selected to move to the next round which is mains exam.it consists of 9 papers including GS paper and optional subject paper. The last stage is personal interview where candidate's personality is assessed. The final merit list is drawn on the basis of marks obtained in the 3 stages. The preparation of IAS exams require lot of hard work and guidance. One can have this guidance in the form of a good coaching centre like Rau's where students are taught effectively through updated teaching-learning methodology. For more information regarding preparation stage of exams one can refer to the blog of Rau's which is a good source of knowledge on this issue.

As around 130 days are let for Prelims, the best way to go about preparing should be based on proper strategy, target based study and timely completion of the targets. And all this must be coupled with daily question solving. thing we must have in mind is the time crunch. So based upon above features there can be many best ways to suit an individual. But still according to me the best strategy for UPSC preparation at this time must be as follows: one should divide the complete syllabus of prelims subject wise and then based on level of preperation each subject must be divided into topics to be covered in specific number of days.now for every day select atleast 2 subjects and set a target for covering the designated topics.at the end of the day solve some question based on the topics you have read.then at the end of week revise all the topics you covered during the week of both the subject and without fail solve more question.if you do this you will have covered your whole syllabius more than once before prelims(which is a must).This the best strategy at this point of time as when there is time crunch one is overwhelmed with what to do and what not to do and in this confusion one ends up doing nothing. So i would suggest do this target based study to be in a position to clear the prelims this year itself. But there may be a chance you would not be able to analyse the syllabus properly and properly divide syllabus into topics, in that case take help of some senior or may be coaching. I think online sites like insights offer this type of program. But i personally i would suggest you to approach some offline coaching centre which can keep a personal check on you if you dont fulfill targets on daily basis. Vajiram offers test series where target is given for every test that may be also helpful. There is also a coaching Jigyasa IAS which offers personal mentorship and target based study, that might be particularly helpful for you at this point of time to prepare. I think they run online program for it also. But whaterver you do dont waste your time running here and there as time will just fly away. So organise yourself and get down to study. All the Best..
