Tips To Crack UPSC 2020 Examination: Prepare A Suitable TimeTable: Analyse your status long before the examination and plan your schedule accordingly. When it comes to civil services exams, last minute preparations never work. Since the civil services exams take place every year, there is always a plenty of time to plan how many days you would want to allot for certain subjects. Remember, slow and steady always wins the race. So early preparations always help than mugging up when the exams are just a month away.  Study And Revision Should Be Part Of Your Syllabus: The vast syllabus of civil service examination can leave anybody in confusion. Hence, you need to plan your studies for a day and for a week. You should plan your study method in such a way that you should be able to read and revise the prescribed subjects as many times as possible or till you feel confident about your preparation. Focus On Basic Concepts: Since those who aspire to help in nation building through civil services need to know what exactly it takes to pass these exams, they should be well aware of the country and significant developments. Thorough knowledge about your country's culture, society and language is an inevitable requirement to be well prepared for the exams. So the preparation does not mean you should be a book-worm but an aspirant with the practical knowledge of his surroundings.  Make notes: As you go through the syllabus, make quick notes. This will help you in revision and better understanding of concerned topics. Are coaching classes necessary? One very simple fact that every civil services aspirant should know is that if one is not mentally prepared and determined enough to understand a subject to the core, one cannot succeed even by attending coaching classes. Those who believe that only coaching classes can help them with useful tips for preparation can join. However, it is always better to study each and every subject in detail with proper understanding instead of preparing for name's sake. Keep Yourself Updated With Current Affairs: Civil services exams are there to test an aspirant's in-depth knowledge about the society he/she is lives in. It is a common myth among the candidates that they should be well aware of what is happening at the international level. Knowledge about international events is also required, but knowing one's own village, district, state and country should be considered as the foundation for one's preparation. This does help in serving one's country very well. Reading Newspapers: The moment one fills up the form for civil services exams, one is advised to read newspapers regularly. Reading English newspapers is advised with a lot of emphasis. However, it is quite important for the civil services exams aspirants to read English as well as other regional language newspapers. The idea here is to be well informed rather than acquiring limited knowledge. One newspaper may provide a news with limited information whereas the same news may be given with a lot of details in another. So be hungry for more than one newspaper to be well informed. Practice Previous Years Question Papers: Solving previous years question papers is important. It is advised to study at least 5 years solved question papers. This kind of activity gives you an idea about the structure of the questions papers and what kind of questions can be asked in the coming exams. Solving question papers of previous years or at least glancing at them may appear a tedious task, but it is a pain worth undergoing. It does boost your confidence and give you a clear picture of what exactly you are going to see in the question papers of upcoming exams. Many civil services related sites have useful question banks at your disposal. So go ahead and utilize them to the fullest and you will experience the leap your personality takes from being blank to being focused and confident. Focus On Your Personality And Communication Skills: Interview is one of the most important parts of the examination. It is vital for you to convey your thoughts clearly to the interviewers. Hence, concentrate on polishing your communication skills and body language. Some candidates are blessed with such skills. And some need to practice to become excellent communicators of their ideas. Candidates with no communication skills can approach those, who have already appeared for the civil services exams, to take useful tips from them. Be Honest To Yourself: The interview part of the civil services exams is not designed to judge one's expertise on a subject. However, a candidate has to speak from the heart or answer all the questions with honesty. There is a common misunderstanding among the candidates that if they speak lies about their hobbies just to get through the interview, it will never help them. The interviewers are there not just to ask questions but also to evaluate a candidate's personality and ability to have a clear understanding that a 'no' is a 'no' it cannot be replaced with a 'yes' and vice versa. So you have to be yourself, and must face the exam and interview honestly.

Before getting into it, There are some questions, you must answer them viz., First, Why do you want to be a civil servant? Because it is like a jungle, either you have to hunt or to be hunted. Without reason of LIVING, you’ll not be able to fight. Second, Do you have second thought in your mind? If you have any other plan in your mind then it’ll divert you from your goal at some time. So be with your internal motivation instead of external and once you decided, do not let anyone change your decision. Then What is UPSC? First read syllabus 2–3 time and also check previous year question papers. Select your optional subject wisely. If possible, choose your graduation subject or any other which you like to read more. Always keep your syllabus with you while studying and do not read the content which is not relevant for your exam. Read selected books and notes but revise again and again. Start with NCERT books and newspaper. Dont waste your time thinking about old or new ncert or shall I study subjectwise or classwise. Pickup any & Follow whichever is okay for you. ‘Your excuse will eat your time’ After completing ncert’s Study static portion because if you couldn’t choose your optional subject then it’ll help you to understand your interest. If you don’t know books, google currently selected officers interviews and follow whichever you want to follow. Essay, current affairs and optional are the important factors. As your time will pass you’ll understand the material ( which) and time (how much) need to complete your task. Join test series because it will help you to record your progress and it will also help you to focus on your weaknesses. Good Luck.

Everyone knows that the UPSC exam is the mother of all written examinations. UPSC exams are the toughest exams as compared to other government exams. So if you think to start preparing for the UPSC exam then keep working hard and hard to crack the UPSC exam. Here some tips to prepare for UPSC exam 2020- Time Management - As you know that time management is an important factor to prepare for all types of government exams, not only for UPSC exams. This time management is possible to manage only for those students who are able to set up a plan and fix a deadline to cover all the portion of the syllabus and divide time equally to each and each subject to cover the UPSC syllabus.t is also essential to understand that most of the time you give for your study that's helps to improve your concepts.Exam pattern - In the UPSC exam there are three stages, Preliminary exams, mains exam, and interview. You cannot reach the subsequent stage without successfully crossing the previous one. Each stage is going to be harder than the previous one. The initial two phases request sound information from the applicant on plenty of topics. The final stage is an interview round they will check your personal knowledge and skills and also check your presence of mind.Practice and Solve Mock Series- It is necessary to keep writing, reading, and solving mock series. If you want mock series online to practice for your preparation of UPSC exams so according to me you can go with the Utkarsh website. They provide the best mock series and you can also download study material from this website.Current Affairs - At the time of preparation it is necessary to know about current affairs so read newspapers and magazines, it helps to improve your general knowledge which is the most important factor to crack UPSC exams. Various sources are available in the market through which you improve your current g.k.

one of the primary factors that make the civil service Exam tough is the exam pattern. it consists of three stages prelims, mains, and interviews. student has to cross each stages to move onto to the next. the level of difficulty increases with each stage. the last stages can also be a tough nut to crack because of the UPSC tests not only the aspirant’s knowledge and ability to write but also their mental strength and ability to deal with situations. it requires a special kind of preparation to overcome the UPSC interviews stage. Another important feature that adds toughness of the exam is the syllabus, as it covers a diverse range of subject, unlike many other Exams.   How to prepare for IAS while working? With less time in your hands, time management is crucial to your preparations. Some to-do list Set a schedule as per your liking and stick to it Find people who are in your situation or in your organization and socialize with them to utilize that time for discussions. You will thus have time to chill with friends who are serious about the IAS exam. It will also fulfill your social needs and keep you stress-free. Look for notes and study material that are short and effective. But some topics you will have to do in-depth studies. Listen to the short news and do not waste time listening to unnecessary discussion-based news unless the topic demands it. Use memory techniques that speed up your learning. Frequently practice giving tests and writing answers. That will work as revision and practice. UPSC SYLLABUS FOR PAPER I – (200 MARKS) DURATION: TWO HOURS (COUNTED FOR THE MERIT RANK IN THE PRELIMS) Current events of national and international importance. History of India and Indian National Movement. Indian and World Geography – Physical, Social, Economic Geography of India and the World. Indian Polity and Governance – Constitution, Political System, Panchayati Raj, Public Policy, Rights Issues, etc. Economic and Social Development Sustainable Development, Poverty, Inclusion, Demographics, Social Sector initiatives, etc. General issues on Environmental Ecology, Bio-diversity and Climate Change – that do not require subject specialization. General Science. UPSC SYLLABUS FOR PAPER-II- (200 MARKS) DURATION: TWO HOURS (NOT COUNTED FOR THE MERIT RANK IN PRELIMS BUT A QUALIFYING PAPER; JUST NEEDS 33% MARKS) Comprehension. Interpersonal skills including communication skills. Logical reasoning and analytical ability. Decision-making and problem-solving. General mental ability. Basic numeracy (numbers and their relations, orders of magnitude, etc.) (Class X level), Data interpretation (charts, graphs, tables, data sufficiency, etc. – Class X level).

“Starting over can be challenging, but also it can be a great opportunity to do things differently” NCERT is the only book which can build your confidence and momentum. Start studying NCERT from class 6 to 12 .NCERT books are written in simple way so that everyone can understand it . Start from class 6th NCERT and read history, geography, polity etc. If you have problems in reading NCERT then you can also watch YouTube video to clear your concept. There's one YouTube channel name EXAMRACE where you can get summary of all chapters of NCERT so it will help you to understanding basics. Start reading newspaper or watch videos on YouTube for current affairs so that you can get idea of what to read or what not to read in newspaper. Atleast give 1 month to fully understand newspaper and don't try to remember or memorise things just read once get essence of every topic that would be sufficient initially. After doing all this , go for higher level book like Bipin chandra for History, laxmikant for Polity, Ramesh singh for economics and so on. Start writing answers also. Whenever you read any topic , create your own question and write that topic in answer format so that you're answer writing also get improve. These all things you can't do in 1 day or 1 week it requires a lot of time and you still have lot of time for preparation. So , start from now and don't try to study 8 hours a day directly initially study only few hours and gradually gradually increase your study hour . You can study as per your wish but be regular and consistent. Gap in studies should be avoided. So best of luck for your UPSC journey. “Start by doing what's necessary; then do what's possible; and suddenly you are doing the impossible”

Upsc is said to be the one of the toughest exam among all the exams wgere in you have to pass all the 3 stages(prelims, mains, interview) in order to get selected. So it is very important for each and every individual preparing for the this exam gets best of the best guidance. One has to be very regular and consistent with his/her efforts and put his 100percent while preparing for this exam. You can check below tips, if it works for you- 1. Revise every subject - On the basic level, covering every subject of civil services preliminary exam is the best approach to clear prelims now. It's not recommended to give priority to any particular book or area thinking that questions will come from that source. Likewise, it's equally important not to miss easy questions from traditional subjects like Economics, Geography, History and Polity. At least, brushing up NCERT books and previous years' question papers would be a good idea if you are time-crunched. 2. Take, Clear mock exams - Writing mock tests arm you with confidence which is the key to success in any examination. 3. Invest on the right books - Picking up recommended books and right study material is of utmost importance. The NCERT books are thought to be must-read by experts as well as successful candidates. 4. Follow Prelims cum Mains Approach - An integrated prelims-cum-mains approach is catching on among civil services aspirants which rely on clearing prelims and mains in a single attempt. Good knowledge of overlapping and non-overlapping areas in the UPSC syllabus for Prelims and Mains certainly gets you competitive mileage over your peers. 5. Go with a relaxed mind on the exam day:All your efforts will go in vain if you lose your cool on the exam day. It's pertinent to read questions carefully and make sure that you do not make silly mistakes. Hope this helps!!!

First of all make your LONG TERM PLAN. It must be with you to compare it with your daily plan and match your speed accordingly. Then divide it(long term plan)in shorter pieces. Suppose if you want to complete Union government in one week then divide it like reading each chapter and making notes each day. On sunday you can revise the whole unit. Your plan should be comprised of Long term plans+ short term strategy. Like that you can cover big syllabus with manageable burden each day. You wont feel overburdened and keep your motivation to study at high level. This really works:), almost for everyone. The most important thing is to keep your resources minimum. Your daily target should not be studied from too many books, articles. And keep saying yourself that whatever you have chosen to read that is enough and and you won’t be attracted by unnecessary lucrative materials in the market. Do not go speedily. everyone has their own speed of learning. Make plan according to your capacity. Do not over do it. It will keep your energy saved. Finally I would say make plan keeping in view all your strengths and weaknesses. Start with what you are weak in and keep your strong subject for later. All the best

Thanks for A2A. It is very subjective. It may change with person to person. But here I want to share about how I had started my preparation. First, understand the syllabus of UPSC. Get an overall idea about the syllabus before starting your actual preparation.Start reading newspaper [The Hindu or Indian Express] on daily basis. Read the news which is relevant for UPSC preparation.Start your preparation with basic NCERTs. These books are written in a very lucid language with rich content and helps us getting involved with the books.After finishing relevant NCERTs, refer to the highly recommended reference books or class notes [if you have joined coaching]. Don’t just read books from cover to cover, be selective.Your approach should not like first I have to study for prelims and then mains exam. You should have integrated approach.Join good test series for prelims as well as for mains. Get your preparation evaluated. Try to work on your weaknesses.Please visit following links for more information. How to start preparation. Anil Pawar's answer to Can I start UPSC preparation from scratch from January 2018? Thanks for reading!

I am not making any presumption about which UPSC Examination you are trying to appear for. Let me explain the universal; approach to all competitive examinations. : Thoroughly familiarise yourself with the syllabus of the Examination. Collect the required Text Books, Guides and other reference materail. PLan a schedule to read and coer the entire syllabus in one year’s time.. Schedule reading for two hours,followed by a break and a summarising exercise, for an hour,on what you read. At the end of the week, revise the summary notes and see if you can answeer any uestions about the topic,in one word,one sentence,one paragraph or one page.If in doubt, do the exrecise, in that order. For each day have two to three reading and summarising schedules. If you are not parallely attending University, increase the sessions to five. But chose different subjects for each session. From the third month on , practise answering the Regular exam papers within the allotted time.Neer exceed the time adissible. Go on increasing your answering speed till you can complete the p[aper in 80 to85 % of the allotted time, and have free time to review the answers. Choose for Optional Paper a subject you have genuine interest in , —one through which you think you can make a difference to the Country [eg; International relations, Foreign Trade and Commerce,GATT and its newer versions, Genetic Modification of Crops to solve India’s food deficit, and so on].If you already don’t know one such subject, take as optioonal one subject you were very good at college an Pursue it to P.G and Doctoral level study,informally, til you can answer the quesions in the exercise I suggested : one word, ,one sentence etc.. Join Debating Socities , read scholarly aricles on General Knowledge and Current Affairs [Read GST/VAT etc]. Write and contribute serious articles to journals and News Papers. Maintain a high standard of spoken and written English and Hindi for effective comunication. In general develop the attitude of service to the Country through your job, and you will be well on the way to getting selected.

Hey. First of all, I hope you are asking this question because you want to serve the nation, the people of the nation and not because your parents want it. Because until it's your own dream, it's not worth it. Yes, that's what I said, a job is only worth it when you want it. This job comes with a lot of love and respect but you will still spend 70% of your life doing this. Better make a right choice, not a forced one. And secondly, there is no right answer for this. Listen to everyone's suggestions and alter all those for yourself. It's important to have your own personal routine that suits your style. People can sit at home with no social interactions but if it doesn't suit you, don't try it. Decide what suits you and your preparation. Important: I am going to tell you what to avoid in the preparation, and what mistakes are most common. Donot blindly follow anyone's advice. Bring logic in every discussion. I had a teacher who told us to study only 4 pages of newspaper, wrong.Plan. Make a plan, starting from prelims, mains, interview. How much do you want to cover. How much hours you need to study to complete that much in that time. And then follow the plan.Check: keep a check on your plan. Ask a friend nor family to check it on you.NEWSPAPER: I can't stress enough on this part. Now again, don't read blindly. Newspaper help in prelims and in mains. You understand which part of the static syllabus ( i.e. that doesn't change with time like polity, history, etc) is important for the year you are preparing . It also helps in giving facts, numbers, data, viewpoint to write in mains answers. What to avoid in newspaper: Politics news, vague statement related articles- the ones that doesn't provide any new viewpoint or any data. You can also ignore sports, hardly 1–2 questions can be asked. Many time no questions are asked on sports. Ignore Delhi times, Bollywood, etc. Newspaper you will be recommended will be the Hindu or India times. Whichever newspaper you read, read it consistency. Note: here, many people will start reading 3–4 newspapers. But it will last only for a few days. It's better to avoid that. Read just one, buy daily. Small consistent steps are valued.Consistency: make a routine that suits you, don't make it hard on yourself. Bring about a few days to relax, meet your people, laugh. But try to keep the pace constant, try to give designated number of hours to studies daily.Revise: syllabus is vast, questions are uncertain. How to make sure right information gets into your mind at the right time ? Revise what all you study. Respected Tina dabi mam says syllabus should be revised thrice before prelims.Syllabus: there are cliche books for basic subjects to start with ; modern history(spectrum) polity (laxmikat, )e environment (shankarIAS) , geography ( GCleong) etc. You can also ask a senior or a teacher.Coaching: it's not a must. Even after coaching, you have to do a lot of self study. It just gives you a starting base . If you are confident, you can proceed by yourself.Understand your weakness and strengths.Here.. UPSC preparation isn't rocket science. The importance is given because of the prestige that comes with it. And it's well deserved, you will be serving people, serving nation. But it's important that before dedicating your precious time, you evaluate that you really want this. That you can dedicate a lot of your time to this. And that you are strong enough to reach the other end. And if you decide to not pursue UPSC, it's okay. Everyone gauges success at different scales ,but all of them uses happiness and satisfaction. It's important you find that in whatever job you choose. I wish you luck!

Well. Being an aspirant I do perceive what the beginners think about the exam and how much they are worried about their preparation. Having no knowledge is no shame. Not everyone is starting from zero knowledge on the subjects they are required to study during the leviathan journey. It depends on how much they can remember the matters they learnt in their school and college. But truth is, that does not matter. UPSC's demand of conceptual clarity more than memorized facts compels every candidates to study their old NCERT books religiously irrespective of their marks obtained in school level exams. So having no knowledge is no shame.Coming to the question, I must say if you are a beginner,do not hesitate to chew the syllabus of UPSC which comes with a notification every year. Read the syllabus, which is always considered as the most useful guidelines for candidates, as many times as you can until memorized. As beginners you must go through the basic NCERT books from class 6 to 12(not of all subjects). You can recapitulate every important chapters which you think necessary. Many argues that reading NCERTs and making notes are waste of time. But there are many including me who have realized how helpful it is to revise all the things before prelims. Sometimes UPSC asks very basic questions directly from NCERT books. After you have done well with NCERTs you should start reading the standard books or coaching materials which you have. I will give you a list of most advanced and highly recommended resources later in the article. Let me not forget to highlight the significance of reading newspapers which constitutes around 60 per cent of current affairs in prelims . The contriubution of newspaper in UPSC CSE is so enormous that all three stages are incomplete with out current affairs questions. In mains papers if you see, the maximum question are asked from current affairs. However, you need to link current affairs with whatever you have read from books. Your analytical ability is primarily tested in the mains stage. So you can not let a single day pass without reading The Hindu or Indian express.Books required for Prelims:1. Indian History: Ancient India by RS Sharma, Medieval India by satish Chandra and Modern India by Rajib Ahir (These books are available in NCERT format also)2. Indian Art and Culture NCERT (Introduction to Indian Art part 1 and2)+ Indian Art and Culture by Nitin Singhania(you can also refer to CCRT website)3. India and World Geography NCERTs (class6 to 12)+ selective study from Certificate Physical and Human Geography by G. C Leong4. Indian EconomyClass 11 and Macro economics of class 12+ books by Sanjiv Verma or Ramesh Singh + the Economic Survey of that year5. Enviroment Shankar IAS updated book 6. India Polity- M. LAxmikant7. National and International importance has to be covered from Newspaper. (Be a regular watcher of Unacademy DNA) Apart from that you should also mug up the monthly Yojana, which comes at the end of months with some decent articles written by some honorable ministers, professors or secretaries of central ministries,on the policies introduced by Central Government. Reading Yojana helps you gain data as well as proficiency in answer writing.Books for Mains1. Indian History- (Ancient india- revise the books you read for prelims analyse the events)(Medieval India by Satish Chandra)(Modern India-A Brief History of Modern India by Rajiv Ahir and India's struggle for independence)(Post Modern india- India since Independence or India after Gandhi)2. World History - Mastering the Modern World History or Coaching materials.3. Indin society- no good book avilable. Get help from coaching material.4 Geography- rely on current affirs more than basic sources.5. Polity- Laxmikant, current affairs, 2nd ARC report, Sarkaria Commission reports, Punchi commission report on centre state relation , Law Commission reports and judgements given by Supreme Courts on issues with are relavant for you.6. Governance- ARC report +current affairs7. International Relation- International Relation by Pavneet Singh for basic+ Current Affairs8. Enviroment - Shankar IAS +Current affairs9. Indian Economy- Current Affairs + Economic Survey9. National security- Cyber Security policy, AFSPA and other current issues10. Disaster Mangement- NDMA guidelines+ ARC report on crisis management+Current affairs11. Ethics, Integrity and Aptitude- basic principles can be studied from online. Practise case study rigorously.Interview is a stage where your personality is tested more than your knowledge. Thus, it is known as personality test. Rather than reading new things, you should focus on and revise what you have read through out the year and current developments. Make a thorough study on the areas and topics you dealt with while filling your DAF. Being aware of yourself boosts your personality considerably.From the above, one must find the huge importance of current affairs in the exam. Arguably,With the progress of time and increasing availability of materials online, UPSC is setting question papers with questions which are more dynamic in nature. But Don't freak out. We have enough sources and free educators who are working hard day and night to provide useful current affairs resources and standard online coaching, free of cost to all. Unacademy, Vision IAS, Insight on India, IAS BaBa are some online websites which provide standard resources and visual presentation. Remember your endless study will not help you to clear the exam until you solve the previous year question papers sincerely and enroll for mock tests. They will shape your mind according to the requirement of the exam and will boost your confidence remarkably.Best of Luck.

What makes any exam tougher? The length of the content.  In this era of “Internet” the main problem is not how to get the best content, just google UPSC and you will get two to three times content of the same topic. There are videos, there are pdfs there are the so called “capsules”, “magazines” and the list goes on… Ask any aspirant do you have study material? and he/she will tell you all the books or video lectures or those “premium” content they bought thinking that buying the study materials will magically be consumed in the brain. It seems the problem is not finding the content but how to actually handle these overloaded content. Let’s look at the basic thing any aspirant do at the end from all those content. They make study notes and then after they actually starts to learn the things And what is the main purpose of Making Study Notes? TO MAKE THE EFFECTIVE REVISION. Now it is becoming clear that the main problem is not to decide which study materials or so called “premium courses” to choose. But the main problem is To go from “study materials” to your own personalised “study notes” and then to make “revision”. Let’s look at the methods people are making study notes to make revision then it seems they are just doing it in traditional ways of making hard copies of it which rise another problem of “Organising”. (Let’s not talk about those ToDo or Notes apps, let’s be honest those are not suitable for making study notes) Feels like Stone Age while making the study notes in traditional ways Right? Enough of the problems now what is the Solution? What if the study notes can be organised well like in tree structure and the reading is from cards of short summary and the best thing is Revision is Automatic.  Make the best study notes and get the automatic revision COMING SOON

First of all go through CSE syllabus, Make a printout of it & just have a look in it daily. Buy or Download NCERTs from 6th to 12th of Subjects (History, Geography, Economics, Polity, Science). There are around 40 books, Which make your basics for CSE. Learn each & everything from NCERTs, Read, Revise & After you are done with three or more times reading, Write notes in very compressed & crisp format. My suggestion is to make only 1 or 2 A4 paper sizs notes for each book. Use indicators , highlighters, diagrams and mnemonics as much as possible. You can learn NCERTs in 3 or 4 months.With NCERTs start reading The Hindu, Well known precise newspaper for CSE preparation & Other is The Indian Express, But my suggestion is to go with The Hindu. In begining allot 2 hours for Newspaper reading daily, after reading for 2 or more month this time gets reduced to 1 hour, depens on person to person, Make very short notes of it in separate notebooks of each subjects like History and Culture, Geography and Environment, Science and Technology, Polity and International Relations And Policy Formation, Economy, Social-Women-Child related issues.Once you are done with NCERTs buy Standard Textbooks of History, Polity, Economy, Geography, Science, Environment, International Relation & Ethics & CSAT.Essential IAS Books For UPSC prelims-History Of Modern India – Bipan Chandra. (History) or India’s Struggle For Independence – Bipan Chandra. (History)India’s Ancient Past – R.S. Sharma. (History)History Of Medieval India – Satish Chandra. (History) or The Wonder That Was India – A.L. Bhasham. (Culture)Indian Art and Culture – Nitin Singhania. (Culture)Geography of India – Majid Husain. (Geography)Oxford School Atlas – Oxford. (Geography)Certificate Physical and Human Geography – Goh Cheng Leong. (Geography)Indian Polity for Civil Services Examinations – M. Laxmikanth. (Polity)Indian Economy – Ramesh Singh. (Economy)Economic Survey. (Economy)Science and Technology in India – TMH. (Science and Technology)Environmental Studies: From Crisis to Cure – Rajagopalan. (Environment)Environment for Civil Services Prelims and Mains – Khuller. (Environment) or Shankar IAS Environment latest versionIndia Year Book (Current Affairs)Manorama Yearbook. (Current Affairs)CSAT Paper – 2 Manual by TMH or CSAT-II – Arihant (CSAT – Paper 2)Analytical Reasoning – M. K. Pandey (CSAT – Paper 2: Analytical Reasoning)Verbal & Non-Verbal Reasoning – R. S.Aggarwal (CSAT Paper 2: Reasoning)Ethics, Integrity & Aptitude - G. Subba RaoAdditional IAS Books for UPSC Mains- Essays for Civil Services – Pulkit Khare (Essay Paper)India After Gandhi – Ramchandra Guha (History – GS1)Norman Lowe OR History of Modern World – Jain and Mathur (World History – GS1)Social Problems In India – Ram Ahuja. (Indian Society – GS1)IAS Mains General Studies Paper 2 (Arihant Manual – GS2)Governance in India for CSE. (Governance – GS2)Pax Indica – Shashi Tharoor. (Foreign Policy – GS2)India and the World by Surendra Kumar. (Foreign Policy – GS2)IAS Mains General Studies – GS3. (Arihant Manual – GS3)India’s National Security: A Reader. (Internal Security – GS3)Challenges to Internal Security of India. (Internal Security – GS3)Lexicon for Ethics, Integrity, and Aptitude. ( Ethics – GS4)IAS Mains General Studies – Ethics. ( Arihant Manual – GS4)My suggestion is to must have those books which are highlighted above in bold fonts.Make Selective reading from standard booksYou can prepare from these books in 5 to 6 months.Choose An Optional Subject, Which You find interesting, which you can grasp easily and do not get bored from it while reading and revising many times. Complete Optional Subject in 1 to 1.5 month with GS preparation.Subscribe Yojana & Kurukshetra which is good magazine for CSE.In Remaining 2 month before Prelims, Revise syllabus-Notes as much as you can.Make Proper time-table for daily, weekly and monthly preparation.Make compressed & crisp notes of whole syllabus which you can revise and grasp easily in your own language.Read, Revise, Analyse & Write notes and Mock test as much as possibleMake your vocabulary sharp as much as you can.Find Motivation to be a Civil Servant.Always Be Positive, Be Enthusiastic to gain knowledge.Do not get upset or low, If get so, So You must have an ideal in your life which makes your higher, inspire you, motivate you. Find your ideal.Have proper diet, sleep and break.Thank you All The Best

I am writing this answer without any idea of your academic credentials & your past track records. The very realization that you know nothing is a good sign, I would say. I too feel to this date that I know nothing, trust me. It is much better to feel this way than have a misplaced self-confidence that you know everything. And this drives me to look for every possible source of knowledge and improve my information and understanding. I would advise you the following: First develop the habit of reading. Once you do that you will start loving the process & that will take care of half of your problems Read any reputed newspaper daily & dont miss out on the editorial. That will update your current affairs knowledge. Buy NCERT books on history, geography, economy, polity etc to build the base for General Knowledge Next step would be to choose your optional subject. Choose the subject you love rather than the one others advise on account of subject being high scoring. Go through CSE syllabus to ascertain & assess the length & breadth of the topic covered. Get the right set of books— not too many , just the relevant ones & optimum number. Set a plan and prepare your routine. Then confine yourself in a room with books around you. Keep faith in yourself. Must avoid cramming. Try to understand and analyse everything you read. Soak things in. Lastly, don't worry about not having guidance. Everything is available online thesedays. There are plethora of advisors & sometimes too many advisors will mess things up. So, it is best to self-assess the progress periodically. Try doing these. I'm sure things will start falling in place. Edit 1 : The change in question now requires answer to be modified accordingly. Suitable amendments will be done in due course.

Hello friends, this is a question that a lot of aspirants might have so, let us try to answer this as briefly as possible. But before we begin, let us break a myth regarding this exam. Myth: You have to be exceptionally brilliant and should possess academic excellence above par in order to clear this exam. Reality: Hardwork - Sincerity - Zeal - these are the three things that you need. You do not need to be academically excellent, you do not need to be exceptionally brilliant. Let us elaborate.Hardwork: hardwork never killed anyone but if you only do ‘hardwork’ your dream of becoming an IAS officer may get stamped out! What we recommend is ‘smart hardwork’ - a type of preparation that is dynamic and quick to adapt to changes, gets work done and most importantly does not create unnecessary stress while you are at it. Example: Do not waste time reading a lot of books. Reason being that reading too many books is going to confuse you in the end, remember that you are preparing for a competitive exam and not for a PhD. Reading the same book 2–3 times will help you here more than reading 2–3 books one time each.Sincerity: this is actually the master-key to success in this exam. If you are not sincere and give up to personal and societal whims on the slightest pretext - like partying, movie dates - you may suffer in the exam. You will instead need to build routines, stick to your study plans and reshape your lifestyle around this exam. Zeal: having a zeal keeps you eager, keeps you ready. You have to be eager to learn new things all of the time and you have to be ready for any question on any topic before the exam, especially the Main Exam and the Personality Test. For this to happen, you may need to motivate yourself every day of your preparation. Lastly, this cannot be overemphasized enough: stay ahead of the competition; stay focussed; stay healthy; most importantly don’t shy away from taking help if you think you need it! With Best Wishes Team Drishti

First, familiarise yourself with the syllabus, then Read NCERTs before opting for standard books. Once you form a stronger base, then shift your focus to standard books. Market and Internet are flooded with so many material, books, coaching notes that its so easy and natural to be lost in this sea. Make sure you study only relevant ones. So, make your booklist and follow it sacredly. Also, Stay tuned with current affairs. The Hindu, Indian Express, Rajya Sabha TV, Lok Sabha TV, AIR News, editorials, current affairs compilation, budget, and economic survey, are some of the important sources. Then, choose optional subject in which either u had done your graduation or as per your interest. Your job is half done if you choose the right optional according to your aptitude and liking. Whatever you study, just keep revising because the syllabus is vast. Moreover, try to develop answer writing skills, it is important that you practise writing well-framed answers, covering all dimensions within the stipulated time. Also, try to solve previous years’ papers. It will not only help you with answer writing practice, but will also give you a fair idea of the exam pattern and help analyse the trend of question papers. Then, you must also join test series of any reputed institutes like KSG India etc. to assess your preparation level. At last I would only like to say that, don’t believe in Luck or Destiny. Consider yourself worthy of UPSC. Confidence is biggest quality needed. Give your heart and soul to this exam for one year. Be totally honest with yourself and assess yourself continuously. Manage your time judiciously. You will definitely clear this exam with sincere hard work. Best of luck and keep total trust in your abilities. You will make it surely.

Since you asked How i start your preparation for UPSC. I wish you all the best, and I congratulate all those who wish to prepare for UPSC, because atleast you guys are sure what you want to prepare. Now I come to HOW…. I am not here to write a long list to do or any magical paragraph, neither i am not going to give philosophy of UPSC or just to repeat all those methods which everyone will tell you. Even we all know how. I am sharing what i did to reach 99.5 in prelims 2019, without a single class, from 80 in my previous attempts. I never attend any coaching neither any paid test series. Now what I did, what We all should do, Again, it will sound simple as i said these are basic structure. You must stick to it. Learn the syllabus first and read them atleast thrice. And you will get 20% idea (ab kya krna hai.) Start with Mains Preparation, Study syllabus of Mains G.S paper, and try to make notes on each and every topic, either from any book, coaching material or internet. Any source you follow, you have to follow the same and try to gain self believe. E.g, GS 1, History is common in both Prelims and mains, except world history. But once you will read Mains syallabus you analytical approach would develope, this is what prelims expect we should be aware of facts and concept both. This tactics, you should follow for the remaining subject as well. Either in Polity Geo or EVS. Previous paper ko aapne apni aankh bnani hai, jitni bar dekhoge utni baar nye nye thoughts and ideas ayenge, kya krna hain, kahan se padhna hain. Now most Basic Question, Why NCERT, As we all need Alphabets for word formation and then comes sentence, similar way NCERT is Alphabet. We have to read it. News paper reading and Mock paper all this we all know, but we did not follow rigoursly. Our casual approach stop us to follow our routine which we all write but after a week. What one should study can be told but how much one should study depends on many things like concentration ,focus ,passion etc but if u can read 8–10 page an hour, 6–8 hr is pretty good in starting and 10–13 during last 2months but don't u need to burn youself u can suit yourself. What one should study here's is the list 1)Economy- NCERT 12TH MACRO ECONOMICS & Ramesh Singh (it may seems lengthy but u can read it more swiftly than other books) 2)Polity - Laxmikant is enough if want to cross check just try to find the ans of previous yr questions . Leong. 4) HISTORY- NCERT (6-12) for modern -spectrum by Rajiv Ahir for ancient- old NCERT by R.S. Sharma. For mediaeval -again old NCERT by Satish Chandra. 5) ecology - shankar IAS 6) art and culture- Nitin Singhania 7) ethics nad integrity- lexicon Niraj Kumar. 8)Dynamic portion- daily hindu , yojna(read gist of this available on websites), Vision IAS monthly current affairs (available on websites) 9) Essays- read hindu editorials ,it will help u form opinion and give you holistic view (although it's more leftist) 10) you can follow unacademy (app) for further improvement. 11) last but not the least make your every single day count no matter what the obligations are.

Preparation for UPSC Civil Service Examination should be done with a proper strategy. One should keep in mind that what worked for one person might not work for all. The time spent on each subject or topic depends on individual to individual. Students should make a strategy keeping in mind the below points. Start with NCERTs. Make notes for revision purposeRead standard books.Take mocksRevise the topics multiple times.Start practicing answer writing, get the answers corrected by your mentors regularly.Keep the resources limited.Read newspapers judiciously and make notes for the same. Compilations should be used for revision purposes. They shouldn't be the primary source for Current Affairs.Students should keep in mind that the preparation for prelims and mains should be done simultaneously. The last 3 months before the prelims can be kept entirely for prelims revision. CSAT should not be considered lightly and should be practiced during this period. Optional Subjects should be completed once or twice over before the prelims and should be thoroughly revised before the mains. Consistent Hardwork, Systematic Approach, and Revision are the keys to clearing this examination. All the Best!

This is a great thread. Here are my two cents. To start off, I'm a vicarious learner (ethics terminology - meaning: Observational learning is learning that occurs through observing the behavior of others; something such as this thread itself) Firstly, the most cost-benefit I found was through Mrunal's video series - ‘How to prepare for UPSC' (How to start UPSC Prelim cum Mains Preparation for General Studies - YouTube) Most important emphasis one can find on this and through all others is that NCERTs are a MUST. The video series will help you to organise your study of them. Secondly, you shall plan your time - both spatially i.e. till the exam comes up and daily. There can be multiple ways. My approach has been to divide the Spatial time, let's says when I have a year, to complete NCERTs, my optional and status portions of GS (Paper 1, Paper 4 and parts of 2 & 3) within first 7–8 months. Then with 3–4 months remaining, plunge into exclusive Prelims prep, with following two test series. Additionally, take help of video sources if you are comfortable with them. With changing times, they have a high throughput. P.S. I don't think religious reading of newspapers is a must. Summary videos online will work just as well. And writing practice depends upon your existing calibre. If you feel that you need to improve, you shall practice a paper a week. This shall get you started. All the best:)

This is the most important question for almost all IAS candidates to think about cracking an IAS test. After joining all coaching classes, there is no initial strategy for the IAS exam. This post lists the best ways to start preparing for the UPSC exam from your home. #1 What is Your Age and Qualification? #2 Know the Basics of the IAS Exam #3 Get the Right Books for IAS Exam #4 Read the Right Newspaper and Magazines #5 Prepare a Schedule and Follow It #6 Test Your Preparation(JOIN TEST SERIES) #7 DAILY ANSWER WRITING PRACTICE The syllabus and reference books are as follows :  Current events of national and international importance. The Hindu, PIB (Press information bureau) History of India and Indian National Movement. Ancient India Old NCERT Medieval India Old NCERT (Focus on art, literature, architecture, culture and socio-economic-political conditions of all these periods ) Modern India -Bipan Chandra Old NCERT (Focus on socio-religious reform movements, Great Revolt of 1857 and the Indian National Movement) Indian and World Geography-Physical, Social, Economic Geography of India and the World. Resources and Development -Class 8th NCERT Fundamentals of physical geography -Class 11th NCERT India: Physical Environment Class11th NCERT Fundamentals of Human Geography -Class 12th NCERT India People and Economy Class12th NCERT Chapter of G.C.Leong (for reference ) Indian Polity and Governance - Constitution, Political System, Panchayati Raj, Public Policy, Rights Issues, etc. Indian Polity -Laxmikant (Don't forget to solve the previous year questions at the back of the book ) NCERT -Our Constitution at Work (11th std) The Hindu Economic and Social Development - Sustainable Development, Poverty, Inclusion, Demographics, Social Sector initiatives, etc. Indian Economic Development Class11 NCERT Basics of Macroeconomics Class 12 NCERT Economic Survey (in brief) Indian Economy: All articles on the economy at mrunal.org(It's a wonderful blog on all eco topics) The Hindu General issues on Environmental Ecology, Bio-diversity, and Climate Change - that do not require subject specialization General Science. The Hindu Biology Class 11 NCERT Biology Class12 NCERT ★Environment- Shankar IAS is best for this if you cover this book along with current affairs so it will helpful for you to tackle this topic question. ★Current affairs-daily reading the Hindu otherwise Indian express is sufficient and VISION IAS, IASBABA, INSIGHTS monthly magazine is best to cover all topics because they give subject wise affairs. ★Lexicon ethics AND IGNOU MATERIALS

Aspirants, when they begin UPSC preparation, are generally confused. They are unsure about how to start, and what to study. UPSC aspirants have numerous queries in their mind regarding exam eligibility, exam pattern, selection process, optional subjects etc. Many are not sure if coaching is essential or not. Their worries are not invalid. As Indian Administrative Service (IAS) is the dream career of millions of aspirants in the country. So here we are going to discuss about Eligibility criteria, Exam process, selection process of UPSC & weather coaching is essential or not.  It is true UPSC exams need good knowledge but it has not means that you have to study all. UPSC have a fixed syllabus they strictly follow that. So it is not compulsory for you to join a coaching class. You can start by yourself , as many sites provide online study material, which is helpful in preparation . But if you think you need proper guidance then you can head towards coaching centers. Here we are going to UPSC exams & preparation tips. ELIGIBILITY To be eligible for UPSC exam one must be graduate or in the final year of his graduation. EXAM PROCESS PRELIMS OBJECTIVE IN NATUREMAINS (DESCRIPTIVE IN NATURE)INTERVIEW PREPARATION STRATEGY Before going to start you preparation you must have to go through the syllabus and previous year question papers so that you have an idea what type of question UPSC asked and what is its level. After analysis make sure what subject you are going to choose as optional in mains examination because it play an important role scoring good marks which can make different in final merit. If you are a beginner that you have to prepare your mind to sit and study for 8–10 hours daily. If you can do that start preparation from basic. Start your preparation by reading NCERT book’s from 8th to 12th level which build your initial concept about what to study. Once you complete NCERT start with standard books. Some of important books are given here Indian Polity for Civil Services Examinations by M. Laxmikanth (Polity)Indian Art and Culture by Nitin Singhania. (Culture)Certificate Physical and Human Geography by Goh Cheng Leong. (Geography)Indian Economy by Ramesh Singh. (Economy)A Brief History of Modern India by Rajiv Ahir (Modern India)Oxford School Atlas by Oxford Publishers. (Geography)Economic Survey by Ministry of Finance. (Economy)For online study material and class notes you can go though this link ONLINE STUDY MATERIAL FOR IAS  Make a habit of reading newspaper daily which help’s you to know what is going in you state, countary, and present world. As second stage MAINS is pen paper mode, so make your writing skill perfect. Practice daily by writing at least one answer. Go through toppers answer sheets, which may help you to understand how to write good answers. PAPER PATTERN OF UPSC Prelims General Studies Paper 1 (200 Marks)CSAT ( 200 Marks (Qualifying Nature)In prelims only GS Paper 1 marks is considered for making cutoff. Paper 2 is of qualifying nature candidate have to score only 33 % in that paper. Candidate who secured minimum qualifying marks decided by UPSC called for Mains Examination. This is pen & paper mode exam Mains of UPSC contains total of nine subject Hindi (250 Marks)English (250 Marks)Eassy Writing (250 Marks)General Studies Paper 1 (250 Marks)General Studies Paper 2 (250 Marks)General Studies Paper 3 (250 Marks)General Studies Paper 4 (250 Marks)Optional Paper 1 (250 Marks)Optional Paper 2 (250 Marks)Hindi & English is qualifying in nature and other seven subjects are considered for section to mains result comes out from total of 1750 marks. INTERVIEW Candidates who scored minimum cutoff marks called for Interview. Interview contains 275 Marks. After completion of interview phase a mart list is made according to the marks scored by student in Mains +Interview. Candidates who get their name in this list get their dream job. I hope this article will help you to overcome your doubts and also in preparation. BEST OF LUCK FOR PREPARATION AND UPSC EXAMS!!!!!!!!!!!!

I may not be able to draw up any daily time table suitable to all aspirants, but here are some tips for target-setting - Target atleast 3 to 4 subjects/topics in 1 day, apart from newspaper. It is better not to get bored with 4 hours of same subject in a day.Always set ‘slightly ambitious’ targets. You will not be able to get 100% success, but that is very normal.Your targets should ideally have 2 layers. Daily and weekly/biweekly. Like doing 4 chapters of Spectrum in a day, and completing 12 in a week.At regular intervals, preferably weekly, check your how well you have fared in reaching the targets. Buckle up if you are missing them by too much margin.Do not get frustrated by the fact that you are losing the will to study after every two weeks. During such phases, watch a movie or spend a day travelling around your place, to refresh the mind.Space your revisions cleverly in the time table. You cannot expect to retain something if you read it today, and then come back to it after a month. So, make sure that a particular topic/subject is not out of your routine for more than 3 to 4 days.Edit : Interested UPSC aspirants may join Scribble for various free initiatives on Civil Service preparation.

Read relevent articles.Watch Unacademy videos. They are good source of knowledge and free of cost. There are other websites like http://Mrunal.com , UPSC IAS Preparation Online, UPSC IAS Syllabus for Mains & Prelims etc you can take help from them.Develope analytical skills and your own outlook. Make a group circle of like minded people and debate current affairs and social causes.Download pdf of NCERT books and read. Make notes out of that and timely revise that. If you will not revise, things will ultimately erase from memory.Develope writing habits. You should start from writing comments on the Editorial in the newspapers and send it to editor. You can also try Quora, internet blogs or social media. But be relevent.All these will help in making strong foundation. As you will be knowing CSE is one of the toughest exam in country. So work smartly. Divide your time between coaching classes and self study. Keep a balence. Write 1–2 answers everyday. Keep yourself update from current affairs.

Hello , As there are many answers on quora about this still I’ll like to add some short imp points: Here are some tips to crack the UPSC Civil Services Exam and become an IAS, IPS or IFS officer. Watch your Routine One of the biggest roadblocks for the CSE is the time management. The exam is conducted over three stages – the Preliminary, Main and the Interview. Each has a pretty large syllabus and the exam extends over a year. Understand the Exam Pattern The UPSC website clearly states the intention of their test. Plan a Structured Study The volume of information, towards an exhaustive preparation, may seem intimidating. Therefore, it is easier to structure the study plan concentrating on building on the basic concepts, usually from the recommended NCERT books. Practice Testing It is essential to keep up a regular habit of writing, reading, analysing, and examining, a content. Revision is a Priority Updated Current Affairs Various sources recommend The Hindu, Economist, The Indian Express Stay Healthy and Engaged And it is most important point. When you practice answer writing, let it be women-sensitive (that is get into habit of using she instead of he, her instead of his, etc.). It will surely fetch you some more marks.Your answers need to be just above-average (= above average writing skills) in Mains to get selected. So, don't waste your time to learn to have flowery and ornamental writing skills. It is NOT required.Prelims is the MAIN HURDLE. Mains is crackable with above average writing skills (if one is well-read).Cracking UPSC CSE is possible (& not impossible). 8-10 hours/day of study is sufficient if you keep your sources limited.Newspaper is your best friend once you have finished reading your limited books multiple times.Coaching is a waste of time/money. Trust your abilities.Be fearless. You will develop abilities along the way that will make you extremely successful in life (even without cracking UPSC!).Have patience.

Since UPSC is a long journey, therefore, it's essential to have monthly, weekly and daily plan for your studies else you would find that even after 6 months of preparation you won't be able to recall what you have studied or attempt question papers. Before setting daily target you must first set your monthly and then weekly target. Don't be too ambitious in setting these targets. It's OK if you are able to manage only 7–8 hours per day. You daily study should have following components: Newspaper Reading Ideally you should start your day by doing through the newspaper. It's best to read newspaper in the morning. Your mind is fresh and ready to absorb new information. Intensive Revision Revise what you studied 1 month, 15 days and 1 week back. Revision, if done well, takes less time but gives rich dividends. Static Subjects Go through HIPEG (History, Polity, Economy, Geography) standard textbooks as these subjects are highest marks fetching. Make sure that you have crystal clear clarity on these subjects. Optional Irrespective of what optional you have, you should daily devote some time to it. Even if you feel that you have an easy optional don't ignore it. Optional marks plays a crucial role in deciding your rank. MINIMISE INTERNET USAGE Internet surfing, reading random newspaper articles does not qualify as preparation. Period. Your time on internet should be with a definite purpose. Ideally you should devote weekends for searching new information. Writing Practice You should daily allocate some time to writing 1–2 answers (GS, Optional) or attempting MCQs. This will prove very effective in the long run. If you are able to maintain the above daily routine then you won't face difficulty in your exams.

here are some tips:Tip #1For coming out successful in the UPSC exam one needs to be well motivated and confident about his/her own abilities because only if one believes in them can they put in 100% efforts. Tip #2To begin with the preparation the candidates should regularly follow one national newspaper and magazines to keep them updated of the latest happenings in and around the world. Tip #3Also the candidates should be well aware of the pattern of the UPSC which is a three stage examination and direct their efforts accordingly. Tip #4The syllabus should be studied well and one by one the topics should be taken up and should be prepared in great detail. Tip #5It is advisable to choose subjects which you are studying or you have already studied. This will help you do well since you already know about the subject. Tip #7Also, a good teacher who can guide you well can prove to be a great advantage because the teacher can plan your schedule so that your efforts are not wasted. Tip #8It is advisable for the candidates to have discussions with fellow candidates on various topics from the syllabus. These discussions help you retain more. Tip #9Though you are putting in your 100% you should also learn the technique of Time Management. All the questions need to be done in a given amount of time. Tip #10The candidates may take coaching classes if necessary but only after a good research should they choose a coaching centre.

If you are thinking to crack upsc by self-study the best method is to select best and authentic books( like Laxmikant for polity –I can show you past 10 years questions from that book, all NCERTs), magazines( like cronical, Yojana, Kurukshetra, Frontline, etc.) and newspapers( like Hindu, Indian Express). Apart from the basic syllabus which comprises mainly of the NCERT books from std. 10 to 12, general awareness is another big chunk of the curriculum for the exam. First, analyze the previous year question papers, there are many good question paper analysis (like wizard strategist for prelims). Second, make your own study plan. That must be flexible. Time must be allowed according to syllabus requirements. Third, make a stringent revision plan. Remember that without proper revisions you cannot consolidate your studies. Fourth only reading books won’t help. You must have to analyze your studies. To analyze your studies proper test series will help you. I said proper test series. Not any random. ( like Vision IAS, Vaziram, Pioneer Academy, etc.) Institutes like Pioneer Academy do provide some Individual guidance programs for the student who are preparing by self-study. Finally, keep in mind to cut yourself some slack. Only you can stop you from achieving your goal. Every exam comes with its ups and downs and it’s best if one doesn’t pressurize themselves over it. Prepare slow and steady( this is a marathon, not 100 mt race), and use every means of expanding your knowledge base.

Assuming that you are a complete beginner and you are referring to UPSC CSE (Civil Services Exam)- Step1: I would suggest you to go through the eligibility once and then read the complete syllabus (prelims and mains) including the optional subjects. Step2: Selecting the optional subject! Read the syllabus of the optionals that you are interested in. Finalise the optional. Step3: now comes the sources; start with the NCERTS and be good with the basics. Then start off with the basic books. You can get the sources for different subjects here and also a tentative timetable… UPSC CSE / IAS 2018: Strategy and Tips to Crack the Examination (Prelims) - Unacademy Step4: next comes the current affairs part… I’d suggest you to read the HINDU newspaper daily and make notes out of it and follow YOJANA, a monthly magazine. One of the biggest roadblocks for the UPSC Exam is the time management. The exam is conducted over three stages – the Preliminary, Main and the Interview. Each has a pretty large syllabus and the exam extends over a year. Most aspirants are full-time students or office-goers who have to schedule their preparation within the time they can manage outside of their regular routine. Being serious about the exam requires a steady focus, and thus a separate time-table to ensure a consistent approach towards assimilating the vast amount of information for the exam. This time management is only possible if the candidates are able to set up a schedule and fix deadlines for when they intend to cover the various portions of the syllabus. To make this possible, candidate requires roper guidance throughout his/her profession which is provided by UPSC PATHSHALA, which is the best online UPSC preparation platform nationwide. There is a personal mentor assigned to the students for making a proper plan for them according to their convenience for efficient and productive studies. He analysis student’s work, clears doubts, gives test series according to student’s level and is connected all the time to help out in the best way he can. Also, live sessions with the mentor are given twice a week to discuss each and everything related to individual’s preparation. UPSC PATHSHALA , www.upscpathshala.com also provides free demo sessions to the students so that they are 100% confident before enrolling and paying for online preparation.

I have not attempted UPSC yet, but in caese I had to prepare, this is how I would proceed. Start with knowing the syllabus Knowing the syllabus is of paramount importance as it helps to plan which subjects to be picked up and how each one should be given time for preparation in a day. Knowing the subjects beforehand helps to assess the competence of oneself. Create a time table A balanced time table, if followed religiously, can hep reap fruits easily. The time table must have time allocated to general studies, newspaper, optional subjects, watching news and interacting with fellow aspirants in a study group. Improve writing skills Writing skills can be a make or break in UPSC exam. I would practice writing an essay everyday and getting it reviewed by mentors or fellow aspirants on a regular basis. Be away from distractions This does not mean locking myself up in a room for years. It just means staying away from unnecessary activities and elements. Social media is not a necessary evil; it can even be helpful. There are communities on Facebook, like this UPSC 2018 aspirants, which can help in preparations. But don’t get addicted to social media. Have a mentor Joining a coaching center or having an online tutor will help in keeping oneself on track. There are many inexpensive coaching websites for UPSC. I find SuperProf to be fairly good. I am not sure if I will ever go the UPSC route, but if I do, this is how I will proceed.

The civil service exams are considered the toughest in India. Even students who are on the whole good at studies, may fall behind due to the complexity of the exam as well as lack of strategic preparation to ace the exam. You have to go the extra mile to excel in this exam. Here are some pro tips on how you can enhance your performance. 1. Preparation for the preliminary exam- To build up on your subject fundamentals, your school books may come in handy again. The most widely recommended and used books for this purpose are the NCERT text books. Be confident of your facts with NCERT class 8 to class 12 books. 2. Work on your General Knowledge- In addition to having your subject basics clear, work on your GK as well. Read, read, read is the key to having a strong hold over General Knowledge. Read the newspaper everyday and note down important facts from the daily. Newspapers are a storehouse of knowledge, you can even purchase Competition Success Review, Yojana and Pratiyogita Darpan etc magazines for the same purpose (they are written keeping in mind the needs of UPSC aspirants). 3. Analysing Past years question papers- Previous years question papers can provide you with an insight of the pattern of questions. You will know the weightage of different questions, the sources used etc. 4. For the Main exam (Written)- Practice writing by picking up a topic everyday. This is the second stage of the exam where you will be tested on your writing skills. You will be expected to give descriptive answers. The best way to practice for this is to write on topics for which you had made notes earlier for current affairs and general knowledge. Choose a new topic everyday from the same and get set for writing. The total time period will be three hours and total marks will be 1750. After giving the prelims exam you will relieved but you do not have time to waste. Within a week, you should get back to work. All you’re extra reading will help now. You need to write more and read less. Again newspapers like the Hindu and NCERT books will help in this stage. 5. Interview Preparation- Do not take the interview lightly. A lot of brain teasers and logical questions are asked. Give yourself a pat on the back if you have reached this stage. There will be five members on the panel who will judge you for your logical aptitude. The panel will assess your personality and see whether you will be a good fit as a public servant or no. Be candid and polite. They are not concerned with the length of the answer, rather they are more bothered about how you answer, your body language, choice of words etc. Simetimes they intentionally ask questions for which they know that there is no correct response, but want to see your reaction to being asked an awkward question. Do not feel overwhelmed, this is basically an assessment of your personality and not your intelligence. Check out Quantel, a consultation platform for collegiates and entrepreneurs on Instagram-@quantel.in

Start with asking your self- Why do you want to do it? Do you really want to do it? Can you study for about 6 hours minimum a day? (assuming that you want to clear it within a year and a half or two). It is not just an exam, it is a process. It requires an investment of the most important resource… TIME. If you are willing to give that time to the exam instead of other mundane things, you are good to go. I’ve seen people collecting/buying all the books, pilling it up and and not looking at it again. Regretting later for the time gone. This exam should be your first and foremost priority (along with your life, your parents and your health), if you are starting for it. Be clear with the above points, and go for it. About what to study- start with NCERTs and a newspaper (The Hindu or Indian express). Know the syllabus well. Refer to sights like UPSC IAS EXAM PREPARATION - INSIGHTS ON INDIA HOMEPAGE - INSIGHTS , Mrunal » Competitive exams Preparation. These are really helpful while preparation. Read toppers interviews, their strategy, timetable and etc. Lastly, enjoy the process. All the best.

response.answer_text: Go through the syllabus UPSC Syllabus – Civil Services Exam Prelims, Mains and InterviewSee previous years papers Question Papers | UPSCChoose an optional wisely How To Select IAS Mains Optional As Per The Latest UPSC SyllabusRead NCERT class 6–12 National Council Of Educational Research And TrainingRead a reputed national daily,preferably The Hindu and make notes.Read basic text books.List is available on internet. Books For UPSC IAS Prelims 2014 - INSIGHTS , Reference Books For UPSC Civil Services Mains 2014 (New Pattern Syllabus) - INSIGHTSVoila, you are enroute to crack the exam depending upon the quality of your study and die hard dedication.

It depends on u.. If u r going for classes then they will lead u strategies and everything.If u r aiming to do it on ur own, then watch the videos on YouTube about strategies of successful candidates and get the idea and make ur own strategy to deal with every single subject.Don't follow strategies of successful candidate blindly. Make ur own which will help u alot.And about starting prepation start with easy subject like Geography with ncerts and complete polity and economy as early as possible coz they will help u alot in current affairs also.

My sister is a UPSC aspirant….what i see her doing that i can share…. 1.Having thorough look into syllabus…u must prepare a/c to demand of syllabus…and what is the exam demanding 2.Newspaper reading and making imp notes out of it…just fr that u can have last min revision….and keep it revising… 3.Having useful apps like IAS BABA,Unacademy,Vision IAS… 4.Reading current affairs magazine… 5.And at the end of the day solving current affairs mcq/quiz…from website of insights and IAS baba… So i think if one is consistent through out his/her preparation journey one can easily sail out through this exam journey easily n smoothly……hope it helps.. Kindly give suggestions in comment section…. Thank you.

Prepare yourself in a way that you are really confident and strong enough to crack this exam. Ask your self that- “Does this is really of your interest or not”?. Don't make any decision forcefully. Because quitting your career path and coming to civil service is definitely a big risk. So be careful while you are taking this decision. 💪Do remember - “ The way you be brave now ,is a terrifying step once upon a time”. 🎈After you are clear with your vision come up with a fixed plan regarding exam.Go through the syllabus and pattern of this exam.Don't be scared!.The first step always requires more confidence than the last one. So be brave enough to move forward. 🎈First read the basic books ( Ncerts) from class 6 to 12. 🎈start reading daily newspaper ( The hindu). 🎈Try to find out what are related and unrelated topics in news paper articles. 🎈Now again go through the books you read(ncerts) and start note making . 🎈You will be comfortable with the upsc exam only when you read the refrence books. So start reading reference books also. 🎈C-sat is mandatory. So it is important that you must be prepared for reasoning ,aptitude and also english comprehension. 🎈If you feel necessary then either join a coaching centre for guiding you or take the help of any online coaching . Self study is the best option that I would suggest. ⏳Time is very precious. Make use of it properly but don't make your self restricted. Enjoy learning.

Very short and precise answer is by studying. :P First check the syllabus of CSE exam 2018 and previous year question paper to understand what type of questions asked in the exam and which part comes most. Figure out your strength and weaknesses and make a genuine time table which you can follow. No need to make a time table for 11–12 hours if you can’t follow it. Try to be true to yourself and your potential. CSE exam is all about hardwork and persistent study and understanding of the subjects. Check out following websites for the syllabus, previous year question paper, question pattern/trend etc. : MrunalIASBABAINSIGHTSUNACADEMYYou will find here book lists as well which you have to study for your preparation. All the Best.

Build strong Basics from the below mentioned books Polity- Laxmikanth Economy - Ncerts and Ramesh Singh latest Edition Environment -NCERT BIO and Shankar IAS History - Spectrum Ancient history : Ncert old 6 and 11 class Medival history Ncert old 7 and 11 class Art and culture : An introduction to Indian Art New class 11 and nitin singhania as reference Geography - all NCERTS Science- NCERT don't stress be selective based on previous year papers Current affairs - The hindu/ Indian express + PIB +AIR spotlight make good notes don't follow websites in the initial stage Try to read one book 10 times rather than 10 different books all the best for your future endeavors

One should start with reading basic level books eg: School books of sciences and social sciences. Developing a habit of reading good and credible newspapers eg: The Hindu and Indian Express for instance.After this basic study, NCERT books are a good way to get to know what this exam actually wants from you.Once you get till this level of preparation, you yourself will be able to distinguish between what is right and what is not from exam point of view. You will be able to understand the difference between hardwork and smartwork as UPSC exam syllabus is virtually unlimited. So, smartwork becomes mandatory.Most importantly, if you have seriously made up your mind for this exam, then START IT TODAY!

Your first step is to complete NCERT book(9th,10th,11th and 12th) of social science within 40 days. In second step you must have depth command on following books History— spectrum Geography— Mahesh Bernwal Polity— lakxmikant ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE-Sankar IAS For economy economic servey, 11 and 12th ncert and Indian economy by I. C. Dhingra book , Dristi IAS magazine also useful. Always remember second step must be completed within 3 months In third steps yojna, kurushetra and one magazine like civil services chronical or Dristi IAS is helpful for your preparation Here you can go through parallely in prelims and mains.Start daily practice set and watch previous year question pattern, 8210707084

Well, UPSC is one of the most competitive examinations in India, where every year, lakhs of candidates appear for the exam. I would like to tell about a friend of mine, who appeared for the UPSC exam last year. To put it in plain words, he cut himself off for a few months, no going out, no meeting with friends, no partying.. :/ He used to study after coming back from his office, but whatever time he dedicated to his studies, he did it with full efficiency. Sadly, he could not clear the exams with the marks he was hoping for, but he now is confident that with more effort, he can crack it next year. So, to crack the UPSC exam, you need to be efficient and dedicated in your studies, and also should keep yourself updated with the current affairs happening in the country right now.

My glib take (important 5 points) : First deconstruct the exam:PT+MAINS+INTERVIEW; Make your preparation accordingly.Don't just follow some random Topper's strategy, develop your own according to your capabilities and study preferences.If an average student requires 10 hours of daily study for 3 year for cracking the exam keeping others paramerts constant, you can evaluate your time required to make a good attempt. e.g. If I study 5 hours, it will take approx 6 years.This exam is not just any exam, basically it will test several skills like Reading, comprehension, writing, critical thinking etc, so prepare this exam with mind to horn your skills, so that you can optimize your results.Don't just hoard resources, filter and refine the your material, be very specific, what you will requiring in accordance with syllabus, note taking is must.Upvote for more!

UPSC exam expects a globally aware citizen to attempt the prompt or topic. The topics must be well dealt in all its aspects. So, an aspirant must be pro to reading a lot of current affairs and general awareness stuff. Learn the important requirements of the UPSC exam, get some books to start preparing according to your syllabus and look out for the right guidance. Also, Having a practice peer group helps a lot in understanding the general trend of admission in college. Get involved in online discussions and open competitions with similar peer group like playing real time questions on EduThrill, comparing your scores among the competitors also helps understand where to apply to secure yourself a seat.

Make the concise plan every day. At the time of sleep do check the progress. Don't forget to sign in test series. Be confident and hit the target. Remember the Gita sloka “Karmanye wadhika raste maa faleshu kadachin” believe in karma not in the result. Take 7–8 hrs sleep. Don't show off that you are preparing for this Giant. Don't believe in rumors and also don't take Baba's Gyan(people who are preparing for 2–3 years) It's a journey please enjoy the process. And last but not least “Hope for best but prepare for worst”. All the best do well!

“Good starting means your half work is done” 1.That’s why the starting of preperation at right time becomes very crucial.If you are at your graduation college(from 2nd year or 3rd year) then start thinking about UPSC and also focus on your graduation subject if your planning to take it as your optional. 2.Make habit of reading newspaper(THE HINDU or INDIAN EXPRESS). 3.Read EDITORIAL nicely and then try to write it in your own language. 4.Read NCERT from class 6 to 12.(Then decide your optional subject) 5.See previous year question paper and try to solve it and then analyze. 6.Go for standard books recommended by TOPPERS. 7.Don’t buy too many books for one subject. 8.Read and revise many times as you can. 9.Watch vedios of MRUNAL and UNACADEMY for better understanding of subjects. 10.Follow INSIGHT and IASBABA for answer writting of mains and see answers of others aspirants and then match with your answeres where you are lacking. 11.Give one hour for physical activities. 12.Stick to SYLLABUS and PREVIOUS PAPERs. 13.Read strategies of toppers and include in your daily routine(Don’t follow blindly).
