the word “required things” could mean a number of things. intellectual traits: mental alertness and attention to comprehend what you read.if you are not active while studying you might miss out on a key aspect. how to sharpen intellectual traits: exercise/nutrition/sleep are the 3 foremost factors that affect brain function.avoid junk food and those with sugar like cold drinks.add more fats and protein in your diet.eat 20 almonds a day, have boiled eggs also.run every morning.running involves both deep breathing as well as coordinated movement of hands and legs.running is a proven way of optimising brain function2. mindset: how you think or the lens through which you see yourself is important.your belief should be that if I follow the right approach you will get the right results.conversely if follow a wrong approach I won't get the right results.never ever repose so much faith in yourself that you forget the importance of right approach.read some toppers’ interviews and take note of important points.you will see a lot of commonalities in the advice given by different toppers.those common points are absolutely non-negotiable.just take note of key points from their interviews.however you should read toppers’ interviews after a certain point. 3. book list: avoid reference books wherever possible.ideally reference book should be read only where school textbooks don’t cover the syllabus well. freedom struggle and polity are the only 2 subjects where you should read a reference book.for subjects like economics, geography and culture school textbooks should suffice.this is because these subjects are well covered in school textbooks 4. learning skills: how to learn is far more important than what to learn.everybody knows the book list.everybody reads the Hindu yet not everybody gets the same result.the difference is created by how you read those books.most people take short notes to reduce the information burden.but this strategy backfires as it limits the perspectives you get from a given topic.ideally you should take notes in question-answer formation to cover all possible questions that might be asked. 5. ability to ignore popular opinions: most people will read vision monthly not because it helps but because others are reading it.candidates fear that if they don’t do what other are doing they may be left behind.in other words candidates sacrifice their selection prospects for short term psychological security. 6. brain optimisation strategies: i.a.s. is no body-building competition. it is a test of your brain function.your brain works very much like combustion engine of a vehicle.it needs oxygen to burn the fuel that you get from food the absence of sufficient oxygen means the fuel is not “burnt” and energy locked in it not released.in the absence of energy you won't be able to sustain your concentration.when you have trouble concentrating you will stop studying altogether.this is why running every morning is important.it increases intake of oxygen.other brain optimisation strategies include yoga and journalling.both are equally important as running.as Abraham Lincoln said, if you give me 6 hours to chop down a tree I'll spend the first 2 sharpening the axe.you must spend some time sharpening your brain.trust me merely reading books doesn't sharpen your brain.running and yoga do. lastly, you must take note of important pieces of advice that you get from different sources and then act on them. no point asking these question if you have no intention to apply these principles.as French author Andre guide said,”everything worth saying has been said already but because nobody listens it must be said again”.

It is the quality of hours put in preparation that matters and not the quantity of hours put in preparation. In simple words, it is the hard work complemented by smart work that gives results in an exam as strenuous as UPSC CSE. Most of the time in preparing for civils services exam go to collecting and preparing quality source material (I would say more than 60%). That is why once you get the source material right, it takes quite less efforts to prepare for the exam. This is where you may find UPSCMENTOR very helpful, where I am myself doing the job of data collection and information building. There is a subtle difference between data and information. On internet and books, you get the data, which also contains a lot much unwanted content from examination point of view. Once you filter the relevant content, it becomes information. This information when absorbed becomes your knowledge, which is tested in the exam. So, at our platform, you get information which is precise, structured yet comprehensive, so that you gain the maximum knowledge needed for the exam. There are many free resources also available, but they mostly serve the data. You have to spend your time and effort in reading that data, and then filtering the important information from that data. So, its upto you, whether you want to save time or whether you want to save money. Irrespective of this choice, the end result would depend upon how much you convert into your knowledge. So to prepare well for upsc cse exam, read high quality content, revise, and practice. Work hard but work smart. I hope it helps you get the picture.

Start by understanding what civil services entails. Then go through the notification and understand the syllabus. After you have understood the process, the next step is deciding your optional. You can consider your graduation subject for this or short list a few subjects and go through standard books for each for a week to form a general understanding and interest. Choose the subject that interests you as it is completely a myth that some optionals perform better than others. You have to understand that you will spend at least 1–2 years with a particular optional, so having interest in it is a must. You can get the booklist from any Topper's blog it is readily available.

First of all see the previous year questions and find the correct answer from book, write the answer which you find and connect it with current activity, any movement, any accident as a examples to justify your written answers, and check where was you wrong in answer writing, have you written only according to your questions or you are going to another topic, Now see the previous year coaching solved notes, what they have done in writing answer and match it with your answer, and learn from solved papers what topic they wrote in answer, which example, which movement, and in which structure they are using in answer writing I want to tell you that the reading of previous year papers make you understand the asking pattern of upsc, you will understand what the upsc want from you, what they expect, now you are able to find out which material needed you in solving those answer. If you don't have the motivation in the first place there is no point in trying something as hard and demanding thing like an UPSC exam , this exam transforms an individual The motivation should come from within, zeal to become an A grade officer and serve the nation , a gazzeted officer ( an official document that is presented in parliament that contains the names of upsc candidates who joins the services after clearing it ) One should never do things because some one told them to do so ( like their parents, friends etc ) or someone in their circle is doing it So they copy them . It will only leave you frustrated after 1–2 attempts because then you will realise you have wasted 1–2 years of your life and still in the same spot the day you begun . UPSC preparation is not rocket science, the more precise your preparation is the most result-oriented you will be. The whole preparation can be broken into 3 steps: Step 1 - Understanding(not just reading) the syllabus and clearing the basics using NCERTs and other prescribed standard books. Step 2 - Making newspaper a part of your life and syncing your current affair preparation with the static part.Also keep looking at previous year papers so that you don't loose track. Step 3 - Revision and Practise …Solve as many test series for prelims and do answer writing practise . Also optional preparation should go side by side because optional decides whether you'd make it to final the list or not..

There's no initial preparation for CSE. Either one is serious or one is not . 2018 CSE is now around the corner . So if you are looking at 18 CSE then begin earnestly but if you are looking at CSE 19 then it's too early. But if you are serious about CSE 19 then widen your reading . Read at least 3 dailies including either Indian express or the Hindu and aone financial paper Write one eassay of 250 words every week on a subject of choice either topical or imaginary Write one précis of an editorial every week . Précis means reduce the editorial into onethirds in your own words . Start talking to someone in English if your proffered lanhuage is English . Same for hindi Watch one episode of west wing every week to pick up spoken English language . Try to solve the previous years papers of CSE prelims . Form a discussant group to discuss topical issues once a week Best wishes
